The '''AIDSRides''' were a series of fundraising events organised by Pallotta TeamWorks which raised more than $105 million for critical AIDS services and medical research.{{Citation needed|date=January 2009}} About half of the money raised directly benefited AIDS patients.{{cite news| url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2001-12-13/news/17632518_1_aids-patients-pat-christen-executive-director-aids-and-hiv | work=The San Francisco Chronicle | title=AIDS Ride planners sue S.F. charity over new race | date=2001-12-13}} In 2001, the [[San Francisco AIDS Foundation]] and the [[Los Angeles Gay and Lesbian Center]] ended their partnership with the California AIDSRide over concerns that not enough money was going to the charities. They hired Honeycutt Group, a consulting firm started by three former Pallotta TeamWorks employees, to organize [[AIDS/LifeCycle]], a similar event. [[Dan Pallotta]] unsuccessfully sued the "copycat" event,{{cite news| url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fsb/fsb_archive/2002/03/01/319484/index.htm | work=CNN | title=Dan Pallotta's bike-tour and walkathon business has raised more than $200 million for AIDS research & other charities. So why do some people hate him so much?* *Hint: Check out the Lexus in his driveway | date=2002-03-01}} but the competition and surrounding controversy made 2002 the event's last year. ==Ride list== Pallotta TeamWorks has organised several AIDSRides in North America:{{cite web |url=http://www.pallottateamworks.com/1_about/history_all.htm |title=About Pallotta TeamWorks |accessdate=2008-02-14 |work=Pallotta TeamWorks Website |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071212165355/http://www.pallottateamworks.com/1_about/history_all.htm |archivedate=2007-12-12 |deadurl=yes |df= }} # California: 1994–2002 # Boston>New York, 1994–2002 # Philadelphia to DC: Philadelphia, Pa. to Washington, D.C., 1996
TeamWorks was fined by Pa. Attorney General for improper fund raising. [http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fsb/fsb_archive/2002/03/01/319484/index.htm] #Florida AIDS Ride from Orlando to Miami (South Beach) 1996-97 # Washington, DC AIDS Ride (NC to DC) 1997–2002 # Heartland: Twin Cities to Chicago, 1996–2002 # Northeast: New York to Boston, or reverse, 1995–2002 # Texas: 1998–2002 # Alaska AIDS Vaccine Ride: 2000–2001 # Montana AIDS Vaccine Ride: 2001 # [[AIDS Vaccine Bike Trek|Montreal to Portland, Maine]]: 2001 # European AIDS Vaccine Ride: 2002 ==See also== * [[Positive pedalers]] * [[Los Angeles Gay and Lesbian Center]] * [[San Francisco AIDS Foundation]] * [[Ride for AIDS Chicago]] * [[List of health related charity fundraisers]] * [[AIDS/LifeCycle]] * [[AIDS Vaccine 200]] * [[Empire State AIDS Ride]] * [[Wisconsin AIDS Ride]] * [[New Jersey Ride Against AIDS]] * California AIDS Ride '94 * [[Charity Treks]] * [[Hill Country Ride for AIDS]] * [[BrakingAIDSRide]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.charitytreks.com Charity Treks Montreal to Portland 10th Anniversary ~ 2011] *[http://pallottateamworks.com/ Pallotta TeamWorks] and [http://www.pallottateamworks.com/about_pallotta.php Pallotta TeamWorks history] *[http://www.aidslifecycle.org/index.html AIDS/LifeCycle | 7-Day 545 Mile Cycling Event to Support HIV/AIDS Services] *[http://rideforAIDS.org Ride for AIDS Chicago | The Midwest's only 2-day, 200-mile cycling Event to Support HIV/AIDS Services] *[http://rfac.org Ride For A Cause] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080615132051/http://www.empirestateaidsride.org/ Empire State AIDS Ride] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080517102949/http://actride.org/ Wisconsin AIDS Ride] *[http://www.njrideagainstaids.org/ New Jersey Ride Against AIDS] *[http://www.tofighthiv.org/site/TR/SFAFCyclingEvent/SFAFEnduranceEventsTrainingProgram?fr_id=1050&pg=entry Seismic Challenge] *[http://www.actioncycling.org/ AIDS Vaccine 200] *[http://www.hillcountryride.org/ Hill Country Ride for AIDS] [[Category:Health-related fundraisers]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS organizations]] [[Category:Lists of events]] {{Cycling-stub}} {{philanthropy-org-stub}}

{{Coord|32|50|0|N|13|10|26|E|region:LY_type:city(1600000)|display=title}} [[File:Victims of Abu Sleem massacre.JPG|thumb|People at a Benghazi rally looking at the photos of victims of Abu Salim prison massacre (February 2011)]] '''Abu Salim prison''' ({{lang-ar|سجن أبو سليم}}) is a [[Supermax|maximum security prison]] in [[Tripoli]], [[Libya]]. The prison was notorious during the rule of [[Muammar Gaddafi]] for alleged mistreatment and human rights abuses, including a massacre in 1996 in which [[Human Rights Watch]] estimated that 1,270 prisoners were killed.<ref name="notorious Abu Salim">{{Cite web|url=http://www.daylife.com/article/0gNNdjv7Qq32E?q=Libya|title=Libya's notorious Abu Salim prison to be emptied|publisher=[[daylife.com]]|access-date=2010-04-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110303080553/http://www.daylife.com/article/0gNNdjv7Qq32E?q=Libya|archive-date=2011-03-03|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://genevalunch.com/blog/2010/03/24/libyas-notorious-abu-salim-prison-to-be-emptied/|title=Libya's notorious Abu Salim prison|publisher=geneva lunch|access-date=2010-04-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711083553/http://genevalunch.com/blog/2010/03/24/libyas-notorious-abu-salim-prison-to-be-emptied/|archive-date=2011-07-11|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name="CNN libya death">{{Cite news|last1=Robertson|first1=Nic|first2=Paul|last2=Cruickshank|url=http://www.edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/africa/11/23/libya.death/index.html|title=Jihadist death threatened Libyan peace deal|newspaper=[[CNN]]|date=23 November 2009|accessdate=28 November 2011}}</ref>
In 2011, when the NTC invited investigators from CNN and other organizations it found only what appeared to be animal bones at that site and announced further investigations.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/09/25/world/africa/libya-mass-grave/ | work=CNN | title=Libya hedges mass grave claim | date=26 September 2011}}</ref>
==Allegations of human rights abuses== [[Amnesty International]] has called for an [[Public inquiry|independent inquiry]] into deaths that occurred there on 29 June 1996,<ref name="amnesty 346">{{Cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org.au/news/comments/346 |title=Investigation needed into prison deaths |publisher=[[Amnesty International]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150317043628/http://www.amnesty.org.au/news/comments/346 |archivedate=2015-03-17 }}</ref> an incident which some have referred to as the '''Abu Salim prison massacre'''.<ref name="court celebrates massacre">{{Cite news|url=http://www.arabicnews.com/ansub/Daily/Day/050624/2005062418.html|title=Libyan legal court celebrates Abu Salim prison massacre|publisher=[[Arabic News]]|date=24 June 2005|access-date=2010-04-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110227211022/http://www.arabicnews.com/ansub/Daily/Day/050624/2005062418.html|archive-date=2011-02-27|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> [[Human Rights Watch]] believes that 1,270 prisoners were killed. HRW also calls the prison a "site of egregious [[human rights violations]]."<ref name="Human Rights Watch 1270">{{Cite web|url= https://www.hrw.org/es/news/2009/10/16/libya-free-all-unjustly-detained-prisoners|title= Libya: Free All Unjustly Detained Prisoners|publisher= [[Human Rights Watch]]}}</ref> Human Rights Watch also stated in a report that they were unable to independently verify the allegations of a massacre. The claims cited by Human Rights Watch are based on the testimony of a single former inmate, Hussein Al Shafa’i, who stated that he did not witness a prisoner being killed: "I could not see the dead prisoners who were shot..."<ref name=HRW>{{cite web|title= Libya: June 1996 Killings at Abu Salim Prison |date=June 27, 2006 |url=https://www.hrw.org/en/news/2006/06/27/libya-june-1996-killings-abu-salim-prison |publisher=Human Rights Watch}}</ref> The figure of over 1200 killed was arrived at by Al Shafa’i allegedly calculating the number of meals he prepared when he was working in the prison's kitchen. Al Shafa'i stated "I was asked by the prison guards to wash the watches that were taken from the bodies of the dead prisoners..."<ref name=HRW/>
Libyan Government rejected the allegations about a massacre in Abu Salim. In May 2005, the Internal Security Agency head of the Great Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya told Human Rights Watch that the prisoners captured some guards and stole weapons from the prison cache. The prisoners and guards died as security personnel tried to restore order, and the government opened an investigation on the order of the Minister of Justice. The Libyan official stated that more than 400 prisoners escaped Abu Salim in four separate break-outs prior to and after the incident: in July 1995, December 1995, June 1996 and July 2001. Among the escapees were men who then fought with Islamist militant groups in Afghanistan, Iran, and Iraq.<ref name=HRW/>
Journalist Lindsey Hilsum explored the topic in her 2012 book "Sandstorm". She met with a number of families who claimed their family members had been at the prison. She describes the massacre number as an uncertain estimate for several reasons; the main problem being the government's long term silence about the whereabouts of prisoners and their condition. She also describes eyewitness accounts of a mass shooting.<ref name=alternet1/>
The families of the disappeared and killed formed a loose association and held numerous protests in Benghazi. Lawyer [[Fathi Terbil]] helped represent them. He was arrested several times for his trouble. [[Saif al-Islam Gaddafi]] (son of the dictator) tried to resolve the issue via his [[Gaddafi International Foundation for Charity Associations]] circa 2007.<ref name=alternet1/>
The Libyan government said in 2009, then controlled by the same people as at the time of the event, that the killings took place amid confrontation between the government and rebels from the [[Libyan Islamic Fighting Group]], and that some 200 guards were killed too.<ref>{{cite news|last=Shuaib|title=Libya appoints judge to probe 1996 prison massacre|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2009/09/06/uk-libya-massacre-idUKTRE5850PJ20090906|accessdate=2 July 2011|date=6 September 2009|work=Reuters UK|agency=Reuters}}</ref> In January 2011, the [[Libyan Arab Jamahiriya]] confirmed that it was carrying out an investigation into the incident along with international investigators.<ref name="ohchr">{{cite web|title=Report of the Working Group on the Universal Periodic Review: Libyan Arab Jamahiriya|url=http://www2.ohchr.org/english/bodies/hrcouncil/docs/16session/A-HRC-16-15.pdf|work=[[Universal Periodic Review]]|publisher=[[United Nations Human Rights Council]], [[United Nations General Assembly]]|accessdate=26 October 2011|date=4 January 2011}}</ref> Statements made in an interview with the BBC by the captured [[Mansour Dhao]], a prominent figure in the Gaddafi regime, provides further evidence for the massacre.<ref>{{Cite news | date=30 October 2011 | title=Gaddafi: 'He died an angry and disappointed man' | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15516678 | work=[[BBC]] | accessdate=31 October 2011}}</ref>
When the [[Arab Spring]] occurred in Tunisia and Egypt, lawyer [[Fathi Terbil]] was amongst the first arrested by Libyan authorities trying to stave off a revolution. The Abu Salim families gathered to protest his imprisonment, and this gathering eventually contributed to the revolution in Libya. [[Abdullah Senussi]], Gaddafi's intelligence chief suspected by many to have been involved in the 1996 massacre, reportedly tried to ask Terbil to make the protests stop.<ref name=alternet1/>
On 25 September 2011, soon after the previous government had been overthrown, the governing [[National Transitional Council]] (NTC) said that a mass grave had been discovered outside the prison.<ref>{{Cite news | date=25 September 2011 | title=More than 1,200 bodies found in Tripoli mass grave | work=[[BBC News]] | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15055109 | accessdate=25 September 2011}}</ref> Khalid al-Sherif, a military spokesman for the NTC, said that the grave was located based on information from captured former regime officials. He stated: "We have discovered the truth about what the Libyan people have been waiting for many years, and it is the bodies and remains of the Abu Salim massacre."<ref>{{Cite news | date=25 September 2011 | title=Mass grave found in Libya with remains of 1,200 | url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics/nation/mass-grave-found-in-libya-with-remains-of-1200/articleshow/10120042.cms | work=[[The Economic Times]] | accessdate=25 September 2011}}</ref> Ibrahim Abu Shim, a member of the committee looking for mass graves, said that investigators believed 1,270 people were buried in the grave but the NTC needed help from the international community to find and identify the remains as they lacked the sophisticated equipment needed for DNA testing.<ref>{{Cite news | title=More than 1,200 bodies found in Tripoli mass grave| date=25 September 2011 | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15055109 | work=[[BBC]] | accessdate=8 January 2012}}</ref> However, when the NTC invited investigators from CNN and other organizations it found only what appeared to be animal bones at that site and announced further investigations.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/09/25/world/africa/libya-mass-grave/ | work=CNN | title=Libya hedges mass grave claim | date=26 September 2011}}</ref>
Before the civil war, the lawyer [[Abdul Hafiz Ghoga]] took the legal representation for the families of people killed in the massacre and negotiated with Gaddafi about compensations.<ref name="HRW_GhogaAbuSalim">{{cite web|title=Update: Death Toll Up to At Least 233 |publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]] |date=February 2011 |url=https://www.hrw.org/node/96642 |accessdate=21 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xKvZxgit?url=http://www.hrw.org/node/96642 |archivedate=20 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> During the uprise Ghoga became speaker of the [[National Transitional Council]], in April 2011 vice president, and held this position until January 2012.<ref>{{cite news |title=Libyan deputy leader steps down after angry protests |first=Richard |last=Connor |url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,15683868,00.html |newspaper=Deutche Welle |date=22 January 2012 |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref>
==Inmates of Abu Salim prison== *[[Ahmed al-Senussi]], a current member of the NTC, was held here by Gaddafi until his release in 2001.<ref name=spiegel>{{cite news |last=Stock |first=Johnathan |title=Gaddafi-Opfer Al-Senussi: Gott entscheidet, was mit dir passiert |url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/0,1518,750656,00.html |accessdate=25 August 2011 |newspaper=[[Der Spiegel]] |date=13 March 2011 |agency=SPIEGEL-Verlag |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/61DGwSOUj?url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/0,1518,750656,00.html |archivedate=2011-08-25 |language=German |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> *Tawfiq Algazwani, a former Libyan citizen who was imprisoned for leading a Human Rights protest in Benghazi. The next day Gaddafi's forces arrested him and took him to Tripoli where he was taken into Abu Salem and imprisoned for 10 years, when he was released he immigrated to Ireland,now in Benghazi and Tripoli. Tawfiq now lives in Dublin, married and has two kids. Tawfiq was released in the 80's and immigrated to Ireland in 1988.
==YouTube videos== On 24 January 2010, the Libyan authorities [[Censorship of YouTube#By country|blocked access to YouTube]] after it featured videos of demonstrations in the Libyan city of [[Benghazi]] by families of detainees who were killed in Abu Salim prison in 1996, and videos of family members of Libyan leader [[Muammar Gaddafi]] at parties.
==Libyan civil war== During the [[2011 Libyan Civil War|Libyan Civil War]] the prison was captured by the rebels on 24 August and all prisoners were set free.<ref>{{Cite web |title=RAW,Libya, Rebels and citizens setting prisoners free from Abu Salim Priso in Tripoli 24.08.2011 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NWHy2jmVocQ |work=[[YouTube]] |author=FreePressTV }}</ref> Among those confirmed to have been freed was volunteer rebel fighter [[Matthew VanDyke]] from Baltimore, Maryland, USA, a member of a rebel unit captured by the Libyan Army in [[Brega]] in March.<ref>{{Cite news |title=American fighting Kadhafi 'lunatics' dreams of free Libya |first=Jay|last=Deshmukh |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=3 October 2011 |work=Google News |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5ggq9gizU50QT6TMAe6WPD-7Xytrw?docId=CNG.63f3ecd569de01fd9d60c41e9a017daa.931 }}</ref><ref name="Feeed CNN">{{cite news|url = http://edition.cnn.com/2011/US/08/25/libya.freed.american/|title = American held in solitary escapes Tripoli prison|author = Phil Gast|work = CNN|date =25 August 2011}}</ref> An international campaign to free VanDyke had described him as a "writer and journalist," but it was later revealed that he was a rebel fighter and prisoner of war.<ref name="Feeed CNN" />

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} '''Accidental incest''' is [[Human sexual activity|sexual activity]] or [[marriage]] between persons who were unaware of a family relationship between them which would be considered [[incest]]uous.
The laws of many jurisdictions [[Void marriage|void incestuous marriages]], even if entered into without awareness of the kinship. If an incestuous relationship is suspected, [[DNA testing]] may be used. Some jurisdictions permit offspring of IVF donations access to donation records or to adoption records.
==Causes== People may be unaware of a [[kinship]] relationship between them in a number of circumstances. For example, [[artificial insemination]] with an anonymous [[sperm donation|donated sperm]] may result in offspring being unaware of any biological relations, such as paternity or half siblings. To reduce the likelihood of accidental incest, fertility clinics usually limit the number of times that a donor's sperm may be used.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9iJlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=RYgNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2368,2279497&dq=accidental-incest |title=Accidental Incest Risk Increases |date=15 March 1979 |work=Edmonton Journal |agency=Associated Press |page=61 |accessdate=23 March 2011 |location=Boston}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=coNSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hwUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6125,3788930&dq=accidental-incest |title=Report From A Test Tube Baby |last=Atallah |first=Lillian |date=19 April 1976 |work=Ocala Star-Banner |page=35 |accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref> Some countries have laws limiting the number of children a donor can father.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/09/30/international/europe/30sperm.html |title=Spreading Scandinavian Genes, Without Viking Boats |last=Alvarez |first=Lizette |date=30 September 2004 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref> while others limit sperm donations based on family numbers to enable one family to have true siblings.
[[Taiwan]] allows those conceived by artificial means to find out if they are related to a person they are considering marrying.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2007/05/11/2003360370 |title=DOH working on provision to stop accidental incest |last=Oung |first=Angelica |date=11 May 2007 |work=The Taipei Times |page=2 |accessdate=23 March 2011 |location=Taiwan}}</ref>
Accidental incest may also arise in the following situations: * Children separated from their family at birth, * [[Child abandonment]],<ref>{{cite book |last=Angelica |first=Jade Christine |title=A Moral Emergency: Breaking the Cycle of Child Sexual Abuse |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-F92TlEyr8oC&pg=PA59&dq=%22accidental+incest%22&ei=-P-HTa2tOKqO0QHR58T9DQ&resnum=2&ved=0CC0Q6AEwATgK&q=%22accidental%20incest%22 |page=59}}</ref> * Sexual exploration.
==Notable cases== *In 2008, it was reported that a British brother and sister, who were twins separated at birth, married without knowing of their relationship. According to the report, the relationship was discovered soon after their wedding, and the marriage was annulled. The case has raised the issue regarding whether adoptions should be kept secret.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/europe/01/11/twins.married/?imw=Y&iref=mpstoryemail |title=Unknowing twins married, lawmaker says |publisher=CNN |accessdate=23 March 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://culturekitchen.com/mole333/blog/accidental_incest_twins_separated_at_birth_marr |title=Accidental Incest: Twins Separated at Birth Marry |last=Sabater |first=Liza |publisher=Culture Kitchen |accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref> Concerns have been raised, however, about whether the story is, in fact, true.<ref>{{cite news |first=Jon |last=Henley |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2008/jan/15/familyandrelationships.jonhenley |title=Did a pair of twins really get married by mistake? |work=The Guardian |accessdate=3 April 2012 |location=London |date=15 January 2008}}</ref> *An engaged couple in South Africa, who had been together for five years and were expecting a child, discovered that they were brother and sister just before their wedding. They were raised separately and met as adults in college. Just before the wedding, their parents met and they came to realize that they were siblings. The couple broke off the relationship after the discovery.<ref>{{cite news |first=Stewart |last=Maclean |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2057081/Engaged-couple-discover-brother-sister-parents-meet-days-wedding.html |title=Engaged couple discover they are brother and sister when their parents meet just before wedding |newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] |date=3 November 2011 |accessdate=9 November 2011}}</ref>

{{short description|Toxic effects of carbon monoxide }} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Carbon monoxide poisoning | synonyms = Carbon monoxide intoxication, carbon monoxide toxicity, carbon monoxide overdose | image = Carbon-monoxide-3D-balls.png | alt = A carbon atom (shown as a grey ball) tripled bonded to an oxygen atom (shown as a red ball). | caption = [[Carbon monoxide]] | field = [[Toxicology]], [[emergency medicine]] | symptoms = [[Headache]], [[dizziness]], weakness, vomiting, [[chest pain]], [[confusion]] | complications = [[Loss of consciousness]], [[arrhythmias]], [[seizures]] | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = [[inhalation|Breathing]] in [[carbon monoxide]] | risks = | diagnosis = [[Carboxyl-hemoglobin]] level:
3% (nonsmokers),
10% (smokers) | differential = [[Cyanide toxicity]], [[alcoholic ketoacidosis]], [[aspirin poisoning]], [[upper respiratory tract infection]]{{cite book|last1=Caterino|first1=Jeffrey M.|last2=Kahan|first2=Scott|title=In a Page: Emergency medicine|date=2003|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|isbn=978-1405103572|page=309|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O0LwFPZDKbsC&pg=PA309|accessdate=2 July 2017|language=en}} | prevention = [[Carbon monoxide detector]]s, venting of [[gas appliances]], maintenance of [[exhaust system]]s | treatment = [[Supportive care]], [[Oxygen therapy|100% oxygen]], [[hyperbaric oxygen therapy]] | medication = | prognosis = Risk of death 1 to 30%. | frequency = >20,000 emergency visits for non-fire related cases per year (US) | deaths = >400 non-fire related a year (US) }} '''Carbon monoxide poisoning''' typically occurs from [[inhalation|breathing]] in [[carbon monoxide]] (CO) at excessive levels.{{cite book|last1=Schottke|first1=David|title=Emergency Medical Responder: Your First Response in Emergency Care|date=2016|publisher=Jones & Bartlett Learning|isbn=978-1284107272|page=224|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gGCHDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA224|accessdate=2 July 2017|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910171934/https://books.google.com/books?id=gGCHDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA224|archivedate=10 September 2017|df=}} Symptoms are often described as "[[flu]]-like" and commonly include [[headache]], [[dizziness]], weakness, vomiting, [[chest pain]], and [[confusion]]. Large exposures can result in [[loss of consciousness]], [[arrhythmias]], [[seizures]], or death. The classically described "cherry red skin" rarely occurs. Long term complications may include feeling tired, trouble with memory, and movement problems. In those [[smoke inhalation|exposed to smoke]], [[cyanide toxicity]] should also be considered.{{cite journal|last1=Guzman|first1=JA|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning.|journal=Critical care clinics|date=October 2012|volume=28|issue=4|pages=537–48|pmid=22998990|doi=10.1016/j.ccc.2012.07.007}} Carbon monoxide poisoning can occur accidentally or as an [[suicide|attempt to end one's life]]. CO is a colorless and odorless gas which is initially non-irritating.{{cite journal|last1=Bleecker|first1=ML|title=Carbon monoxide intoxication|journal=Handbook of clinical neurology|date=2015|volume=131|pages=191–203|pmid=26563790|doi=10.1016/B978-0-444-62627-1.00024-X|series=Handbook of Clinical Neurology|isbn=978-0444626271}} It is produced during [[incomplete combustion|incomplete burning]] of [[organic matter]]. This can occur from [[motor vehicles]], heaters, or cooking equipment that run on [[carbon-based fuel]]s. It can also occur from exposure to [[methylene chloride]]. Carbon monoxide primarily causes adverse effects by combining with [[hemoglobin]] to form [[carboxyhemoglobin]] (HbCO) preventing the [[blood]] from carrying [[oxygen]]. Additionally, [[myoglobin]] and [[mitochondria]]l [[cytochrome oxidase]] are affected. Diagnosis is based on a HbCO level of more than 3% among nonsmokers and more than 10% among smokers. Efforts to prevent poisoning include [[carbon monoxide detector]]s, proper venting of [[gas appliances]], keeping chimneys clean, and keeping [[exhaust system]]s of vehicles in good repair.{{cite web|last1=Health|first1=National Center for Environmental|title=Carbon Monoxide Poisoning – Frequently Asked Questions|url=https://www.cdc.gov/co/faqs.htm|website=www.cdc.gov|accessdate=2 July 2017|language=en-us|date=30 December 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170705012403/https://www.cdc.gov/co/faqs.htm|archivedate=5 July 2017|df=}} Treatment of poisoning generally consists of giving [[oxygen therapy|100% oxygen]] along with [[supportive care]]. This should generally be carried out until symptoms are no longer present and the HbCO level is less than 10%. While [[hyperbaric oxygen therapy]] is used for severe poisonings, the benefit over standard oxygen delivery is unclear.{{cite journal|last1=Buckley|first1=NA|last2=Juurlink|first2=DN|last3=Isbister|first3=G|last4=Bennett|first4=MH|last5=Lavonas|first5=EJ|title=Hyperbaric oxygen for carbon monoxide poisoning.|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=13 April 2011|issue=4|pages=CD002041|pmid=21491385|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD002041.pub3}} The risk of death among those affected is between 1 and 30%. Carbon monoxide poisoning is relatively common, resulting in more than 20,000 [[emergency department]] visits a year in the United States.{{cite book|last1=Penney|first1=David G.|title=Carbon Monoxide Poisoning|date=2007|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-0849384189|page=569|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=793KBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA569|accessdate=2 July 2017|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910171934/https://books.google.com/books?id=793KBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA569|archivedate=10 September 2017|df=}} It is the most common type of fatal poisoning in many countries.{{cite journal | author=Omaye ST | title=Metabolic modulation of carbon monoxide toxicity | journal=Toxicology |date=Nov 2002 | pages=139–50 | volume=180 | issue=2 | pmid=12324190 | doi=10.1016/S0300-483X(02)00387-6 }} In the United States non-fire related cases results in more than 400 deaths a year. Poisonings occur more often in the winter, particularly from the use of [[portable generators]] during [[power outage]]s.{{cite book|last1=Ferri|first1=Fred F.|title=Ferri's Clinical Advisor 2017 E-Book: 5 Books in 1|date=2016|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=978-0323448383|pages=227–28|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rRhCDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA227|accessdate=2 July 2017|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910171934/https://books.google.com/books?id=rRhCDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA227|archivedate=10 September 2017|df=}} The toxic effects of CO have been known since [[ancient history]].{{cite journal|last1=Blumenthal|first1=I|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning.|journal=Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine|date=June 2001|volume=94|issue=6|pages=270–72|pmid=11387414|doi=10.1177/014107680109400604|pmc=1281520}} The realization that hemoglobin was affected by CO was determined in 1857. == Signs and symptoms == Carbon monoxide is not toxic to all forms of life. Its harmful effects are due to binding with hemoglobin so its danger to organisms that do not use this compound is doubtful. It thus has no effect on photosynthesising plants.{{cite web|url=http://ces.iisc.ernet.in/energy/HC270799/HDL/ENV/enven/vol321.htm|title=Carbon monoxide|work=ernet.in|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140414051805/http://ces.iisc.ernet.in/energy/HC270799/HDL/ENV/enven/vol321.htm|archivedate=2014-04-14|df=}} It is easily absorbed through the lungs. Inhaling the gas can lead to [[Cerebral hypoxia|hypoxic injury]], [[Brain damage|nervous system damage]], and even [[death]]. Different people and populations may have different carbon monoxide tolerance levels.{{cite journal|vauthors=Raub JA, Mathieu-Nolf M, Hampson NB, Thom SR |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning-a public health perspective|journal=Toxicology|date=April 2000|pages=1–14|volume=145|issue=1|pmid=10771127|doi=10.1016/S0300-483X(99)00217-6|subscription=yes}} On average, exposures at 100 [[parts per million|ppm]] or greater is dangerous to human health. In the [[United States]], the [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration|OSHA]] limits long-term workplace exposure levels to less than 50 ppm averaged over an 8-hour period;{{cite web|url=https://www.osha.gov/OshDoc/data_General_Facts/carbonmonoxide-factsheet.pdf|title=OSHA Fact Sheet: Carbon Monoxide|accessdate=2009-09-14|publisher=United States National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090826181843/http://osha.gov/OshDoc/data_General_Facts/carbonmonoxide-factsheet.pdf|archivedate=2009-08-26|df=}} in addition, employees are to be removed from any [[confined space]] if an upper limit ("ceiling") of 100 ppm is reached.{{cite web |url=https://www.osha.gov/pls/oshaweb/owadisp.show_document?p_table=STANDARDS&p_id=10366 |title=Carbon monoxide – 29 CFR Part 1917 Section 1917.24 |accessdate=2013-05-27 |publisher=United States Department of Labor: Occupational Safety and Health Administration |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523211713/http://www.osha.gov/pls/oshaweb/owadisp.show_document?p_table=STANDARDS&p_id=10366 |archivedate=2013-05-23 |df= }} Carbon monoxide exposure may lead to a significantly shorter [[life expectancy|life span]] due to [[heart]] damage.{{cite journal|vauthors=Henry CR, Satran D, Lindgren B, Adkinson C, Nicholson CI, Henry TD |title= Myocardial Injury and Long-term Mortality Following Moderate to Severe Carbon Monoxide Poisoning|journal=JAMA|date=January 2006|volume=295|pages=398–402|doi= 10.1001/jama.295.4.398|pmid=16434630|issue= 4|url= http://jama.ama-assn.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=16434630|format= Free full text}} The carbon monoxide tolerance level for any person is altered by several factors, including activity level, [[Ventilation (physiology)|rate of ventilation]], a pre-existing [[Cerebrum|cerebral]] or [[cardiovascular disease]], [[cardiac output]], [[anemia]], [[sickle cell disease]] and other hematological disorders, [[barometric pressure]], and [[metabolic rate]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lungusa.org/site/pp.asp?c=dvLUK9O0E&b=35375|title=Carbon Monoxide|accessdate=2009-09-14|publisher=American Lung Association|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080528195959/http://www.lungusa.org/site/pp.asp?c=dvLUK9O0E&b=35375 |archivedate =2008-05-28|deadurl=yes}}{{cite journal|author=Lipman GS|title=Carbon monoxide toxicity at high altitude|journal=Wilderness & Environmental Medicine|year=2006|pages=144–45|volume=17|issue=2|pmid=16805152|doi=10.1580/1080-6032(2006)17[144:CMTAHA]2.0.CO;2}}{{cite book|author=first draft prepared by Mr J. Raub.|title=Environmental Health Criteria 213 (Carbon Monoxide)|publisher=International Programme on Chemical Safety, World Health Organization|location=Geneva|year=1999|pages=|isbn=9241572132}} {| class="wikitable" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; border: none;" |+Effects of carbon monoxide in relation to the concentration in parts per million in the air:{{cite journal|author=Goldstein M|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Journal of Emergency Nursing|volume=34|issue=6|pages=538–42|date=December 2008|pmid=19022078|doi=10.1016/j.jen.2007.11.014}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Struttmann T, Scheerer A, Prince TS, Goldstein LA |title=Unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning from an unlikely source|journal=The Journal of the American Board of Family Practice|volume=11|issue=6|pages=481–84|date=Nov 1998|pmid=9876005|doi=10.3122/jabfm.11.6.481}} !Concentration !Symptoms |- |35 ppm (0.0035%) |Headache and dizziness within six to eight hours of constant exposure |- |100 ppm (0.01%) |Slight headache in two to three hours |- |200 ppm (0.02%) |Slight headache within two to three hours; loss of judgment |- |400 ppm (0.04%) |Frontal headache within one to two hours |- |800 ppm (0.08%) | Dizziness, nausea, and convulsions within 45 min; insensible within 2 hours |- |1,600 ppm (0.16%) |Headache, [[tachycardia|increased heart rate]], dizziness, and nausea within 20 min; death in less than 2 hours |- |3,200 ppm (0.32%) |Headache, dizziness and nausea in five to ten minutes. Death within 30 minutes. |- |6,400 ppm (0.64%) |Headache and dizziness in one to two minutes. Convulsions, respiratory arrest, and death in less than 20 minutes. |- |12,800 ppm (1.28%) |Unconsciousness after 2–3 breaths. Death in less than three minutes. |- |} === Acute poisoning === [[File:CO toxicity symptoms (en).jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|CO toxicity symptoms]] The main manifestations of carbon monoxide poisoning develop in the organ systems most dependent on oxygen use, the [[central nervous system]] and the [[heart]]. The initial symptoms of acute carbon monoxide poisoning include [[headache]], [[nausea]], [[malaise]], and [[fatigue (medical)|fatigue]].{{cite journal|vauthors=Hardy KR, Thom SR |title=Pathophysiology and treatment of carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Journal of Toxicology. Clinical Toxicology|year=1994|pages=613–29|volume=32|issue=6|pmid=7966524|doi=10.3109/15563659409017973}} These symptoms are often mistaken for a virus such as [[influenza]] or other illnesses such as [[food poisoning]] or [[gastroenteritis]].{{cite book |title=Goldfrank's toxicologic emergencies |publisher=McGraw-Hill |location=New York |year=2002 |edition=7th |pages=1689–1704 |chapter=Carbon Monoxide |isbn=0071360018 |author1=Lewis Goldfrank |author2=Neal Flomenbaum |author3=Neal Lewin |author4=Mary Ann Howland |author5=Robert Hoffman |author6=Lewis Nelson}} Headache is the most common symptom of acute carbon monoxide poisoning; it is often described as dull, frontal, and continuous.{{cite journal|vauthors=Hampson NB, Hampson LA |title=Characteristics of headache associated with acute carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Headache|volume=42|issue=3|pages=220–23|date=March 2002|pmid=11903546|doi=10.1046/j.1526-4610.2002.02055.x}} Increasing exposure produces cardiac abnormalities including [[tachycardia|fast heart rate]], [[hypotension|low blood pressure]], and [[cardiac arrhythmia]];{{cite journal |vauthors=Tritapepe L, Macchiarelli G, Rocco M, Scopinaro F, Schillaci O, Martuscelli E, Motta PM |title=Functional and ultrastructural evidence of myocardial stunning after acute carbon monoxide poisoning |journal=Critical Care Medicine |volume=26 |issue=4 |pages=797–801 |date=April 1998 |pmid=9559621 |doi=10.1097/00003246-199804000-00034}} [[central nervous system]] symptoms include [[delirium]], [[hallucination]]s, [[dizziness]], [[ataxia|unsteady gait]], [[confusion]], [[seizures]], [[central nervous system depression]], [[unconsciousness]], [[respiratory arrest]], and [[death]].{{cite journal|author=Weaver LK|title=Clinical practice. Carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|volume=360|issue=12|pages=1217–25|date=March 2009|pmid=19297574|doi=10.1056/NEJMcp0808891|url=http://content.nejm.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=short&pmid=19297574&promo=ONFLNS19}} Less common symptoms of acute carbon monoxide poisoning include [[myocardial ischemia]], [[atrial fibrillation]], [[pneumonia]], [[pulmonary edema]], [[hyperglycemia|high blood sugar]], [[lactic acidosis]], [[rhabdomyolysis|muscle necrosis]], [[acute kidney failure]], [[skin lesion]]s, and visual and auditory problems.{{cite journal|author=Choi IS|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning: systemic manifestations and complications|journal=Journal of Korean Medical Science|date=June 2001|pages=253–61|volume=16|issue=3|pmid=11410684|url=http://jkms.org/DOIx.php?id=10.3346/jkms.2001.16.3.253|doi-access=free |doi=10.3346/jkms.2001.16.3.253|pmc=3054741}}{{cite journal |author=Marius-Nunez AL |title=Myocardial infarction with normal coronary arteries after acute exposure to carbon monoxide |journal=Chest |volume=97 |issue=2 |pages=491–94 |date=February 1990 |pmid=2298080 |doi=10.1378/chest.97.2.491}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Gandini C, Castoldi AF, Candura SM, Locatelli C, Butera R, Priori S, Manzo L |title=Carbon monoxide cardiotoxicity |journal=Journal of Toxicology. Clinical Toxicology |volume=39 |issue=1 |pages=35–44 |year=2001 |pmid=11327225 |doi=10.1081/CLT-100102878}}{{cite journal |author=Sokal JA |title=The effect of exposure duration on the blood level of glucose, pyruvate and lactate in acute carbon monoxide intoxication in man |journal=Journal of Applied Toxicology: JAT |volume=5 |issue=6 |pages=395–97 |date=December 1985 |pmid=4078220 |doi=10.1002/jat.2550050611}} One of the major concerns following acute carbon monoxide poisoning is the severe delayed neurological manifestations that may occur. Problems may include difficulty with higher intellectual functions, [[memory loss|short-term memory loss]], [[dementia]], [[amnesia]], [[psychosis]], irritability, a strange [[gait]], speech disturbances, [[Parkinson's disease]]-like syndromes, [[cortical blindness]], and a [[Depression (mood)|depressed mood]].{{cite journal|author=Choi IS|title=Delayed neurologic sequelae in carbon monoxide intoxication|journal=Archives of Neurology|volume=40|issue=7|pages=433–35|date=July 1983|pmid=6860181|doi=10.1001/archneur.1983.04050070063016|url=http://archneur.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=582033|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120819232412/http://archneur.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=582033|archivedate=2012-08-19|df=}} Depression may occur in those who did not have pre-existing depression.{{cite journal|vauthors=Roohi F, Kula RW, Mehta N |title=Twenty-nine years after carbon monoxide intoxication|journal=Clinical Neurology and Neurosurgery|date=July 2001|pages=92–95|volume=103|issue=2|pmid=11516551|doi=10.1016/S0303-8467(01)00119-6}} These delayed neurological [[sequelae]] may occur in up to 50% of poisoned people after 2 to 40 days. It is difficult to predict who will develop delayed sequelae; however, advanced age, loss of consciousness while poisoned, and initial neurological abnormalities may increase the chance of developing delayed symptoms.{{cite journal|vauthors=Myers RA, Snyder SK, Emhoff TA |title=Subacute sequelae of carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Annals of Emergency Medicine|volume=14|issue=12|pages=1163–67|date=December 1985|pmid=4061987|doi=10.1016/S0196-0644(85)81022-2}} One classic sign of carbon monoxide poisoning is more often seen in the dead rather than the living – people have been described as looking red-cheeked and healthy (see below). However, since this "cherry-red" appearance is common only in the deceased, and is unusual in living people, it is not considered a useful diagnostic sign in clinical medicine. In pathological (autopsy) examination the ruddy appearance of carbon monoxide poisoning is notable because unembalmed dead persons are normally bluish and pale, whereas dead carbon-monoxide poisoned persons may simply appear unusually lifelike in coloration.{{cite journal|author=Simini B|title=Cherry-red discolouration in carbon monoxide poisoning |journal=Lancet| volume=352|issue=9134| page=1154|date=October 1998|pmid=9798630|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(05)79807-X}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Brooks DE, Lin E, Ahktar J |title=What is cherry red, and who cares?|journal= [[The Journal of Emergency Medicine]] |date=February 2002|pages=213–14|volume=22|issue=2|pmid=11858933|doi=10.1016/S0736-4679(01)00469-3}} The colorant effect of carbon monoxide in such postmortem circumstances is thus analogous to its use as a red colorant in the commercial meat-packing industry. === Chronic poisoning === Chronic exposure to relatively low levels of carbon monoxide may cause persistent headaches, lightheadedness, depression, confusion, memory loss, nausea, hearing disorders and vomiting.{{cite journal|vauthors=Fawcett TA, Moon RE, Fracica PJ, Mebane GY, Theil DR, Piantadosi CA |title=Warehouse workers' headache. Carbon monoxide poisoning from propane-fueled forklifts|journal=Journal of Occupational Medicine|date=January 1992|pages=12–15|volume=34|issue=1|pmid=1552375}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/939229378|title=The Nordic Expert Group for criteria documentation of health risks from chemicals. 142, Occupational exposure to chemicals and hearing impairment|last=Johnson|first= Ann-Christin|date=2009|publisher=University of Gothenburg|others=Morata, Thais C.|isbn=978-9185971213|location=Göteborg|oclc=939229378}} It is unknown whether low-level chronic exposure may cause permanent neurological damage. Typically, upon removal from exposure to carbon monoxide, symptoms usually resolve themselves, unless there has been an episode of severe acute poisoning. However, one case noted permanent memory loss and learning problems after a 3-year exposure to relatively low levels of carbon monoxide from a faulty furnace.{{cite journal|author=Ryan CM|title=Memory disturbances following chronic, low-level carbon monoxide exposure|journal=Archives of Clinical Neuropsychology|year=1990|pages=59–67|volume=5|issue=1|pmid=14589544|doi=10.1016/0887-6177(90)90007-C}} Chronic exposure may worsen cardiovascular symptoms in some people. Chronic carbon monoxide exposure might increase the risk of developing atherosclerosis.{{cite journal|last=Davutoglu|first=V|title=Chronic carbon monoxide exposure is associated with the increases in carotid intima-media thickness and C-reactive protein level|journal=Tohoku J Exp Med|date=November 2009|volume=219|issue=3|pages=201–06|doi=10.1620/tjem.219.201|pmid=19851048}}{{cite book|last=Shephard|first=Roy|title=Carbon Monoxide The Silent Killer|year=1983|publisher=Charles C Thomas|location=Springfield Illinois|pages=93–96}} Long-term exposures to carbon monoxide present the greatest risk to persons with [[coronary heart disease]] and in females who are pregnant.{{cite journal|doi=10.1056/NEJM198911233212102|vauthors=Allred EN, Bleecker ER, Chaitman BR, Dahms TE, Gottlieb SO, Hackney JD, Pagano M, Selvester RH, Walden SM, Warren J |title=Short-term effects of carbon monoxide exposure on the exercise performance of subjects with coronary artery disease|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|date=Nov 1989|pages=1426–32|volume=321|issue=21|pmid=2682242|url=}} In experimental animals, carbon monoxide appears to worsen noise-induced hearing loss at noise exposure conditions that would have limited effects on hearing otherwise.{{cite journal|last1=Fechter|first1=LD|title=Promotion of noise-induced hearing loss by chemical contaminants|journal=Journal of toxicology and environmental health. Part A|date=2004|volume=67|issue=8–10|pages=727–40|doi=10.1080/15287390490428206|pmid=15192865}} In humans, hearing loss has been reported following carbon monoxide poisoning. Unlike the findings in animal studies, noise exposure was not a necessary factor for the auditory problems to occur. == Causes == {| class="wikitable" style = "float: right; margin-left:15px; text-align:center" !Concentration !Source |- |0.1 ppm |Natural atmosphere level ([[MOPITT]]){{cite book | author =Committee on Medical and Biological Effects of Environmental Pollutants | title = Carbon Monoxide | publisher = National Academy of Sciences| location = Washington, DC| year =1977 | page = 29| doi = | isbn =0309026318 }} |- |0.5 to 5 ppm |Average level in homes{{cite web| title =An Introduction to Indoor Air Quality: Carbon Monoxide (CO)| author =Green W| publisher =United States Environmental Protection Agency| url =http://www.epa.gov/iaq/co.html| doi =| accessdate =2008-12-16| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20081218112704/http://www.epa.gov/iaq/co.html| archivedate =2008-12-18| df =}} |- |5 to 15 ppm |Near properly adjusted gas stoves in homes |- |100 to 200 ppm |Exhaust from automobiles in the [[Mexico City]] central area{{cite book | last = Singer | first = Siegfried Fred | title = The Changing Global Environment | publisher = [[D. Reidel]] Publishing Company| location = Dordrecht| page = 90| doi = | isbn = }} |- |5,000 ppm |Exhaust from a home wood fire{{cite web | title =What Do Carbon Monoxide Levels Mean? | author =Gosink T | work =Alaska Science Forum | publisher =Geophysical Institute, University of Alaska Fairbanks | date =1983-01-28 | url =http://www.gi.alaska.edu/ScienceForum/ASF5/588.html | accessdate =2008-12-16 | deadurl =no | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20081225113654/http://www.gi.alaska.edu/ScienceForum/ASF5/588.html | archivedate =2008-12-25 | df = }} |- |7,000 ppm |Undiluted warm car exhaust without a [[catalytic converter]] |- |30,000 ppm |[[Afterdamp]] following an explosion in a coal mine{{citation | last = Roberts | first = H C W | title = Report on the causes of, and circumstances attending, the explosion which occurred at Easington Colliery, County Durham, on the 29th May, 1951. | date = September 1952 | publisher = Her Majesty's Stationery Office | publication-place = London | series = Cmd 8646 | format = PDF | url = http://hdl.handle.net/1842/5365 | page = 39 }} |} Carbon monoxide is a product of combustion of organic matter under conditions of restricted oxygen supply, which prevents complete [[oxidation]] to [[carbon dioxide]] (CO2). Sources of carbon monoxide include cigarette smoke, house fires, faulty [[furnace]]s, heaters, [[wood-burning stove]]s,{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/man-died-from-carbon-monoxide-poisoning-after-using-heat-beads-in-greystanes-home-20150718-gif8d8.html|title=Man died from carbon monoxide poisoning after using 'heat beads' in Greystanes home|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150719131747/http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/man-died-from-carbon-monoxide-poisoning-after-using-heat-beads-in-greystanes-home-20150718-gif8d8.html|archivedate=2015-07-19|df=}} [[internal combustion]] [[vehicle exhaust]], [[electrical generator]]s, [[propane]]-fueled equipment such as portable stoves, and gasoline-powered tools such as [[leaf blower]]s, lawn mowers, high-pressure washers, concrete cutting saws, power trowels, and welders.{{cite journal|vauthors=Marc B, Bouchez-Buvry A, Wepierre JL, Boniol L, Vaquero P, Garnier M |title=Carbon-monoxide poisoning in young drug addicts due to indoor use of a gasoline-powered generator|journal=Journal of Clinical Forensic Medicine|volume=8|issue=2|pages=54–56|date=June 2001|pmid=16083675|doi=10.1054/jcfm.2001.0474}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Johnson C, Moran J, Paine S, Anderson H, Breysse P |title=Abatement of toxic levels of carbon monoxide in Seattle ice-skating rinks|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=65|issue=10|pages=1087–90|date=October 1975|pmid=1163706|doi=10.2105/AJPH.65.10.1087|pmc=1776025}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/co/|title=NIOSH Carbon Monoxide Hazards from Small Gasoline Powered Engines|accessdate=2007-10-15|publisher=United States National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071029032750/http://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/co/|archivedate=2007-10-29|df=}}{{cite journal |vauthors=Fife CE, Smith LA, Maus EA, McCarthy JJ, Koehler MZ, Hawkins T, Hampson NB |title=Dying to play video games: carbon monoxide poisoning from electrical generators used after hurricane Ike |journal=Pediatrics |volume=123 |issue=6 |pages=e1035–38 |date=June 2009 |pmid=19482736 |doi=10.1542/peds.2008-3273}}{{cite report|author=Emmerich, SJ|date=July 2011|title=Measured CO Concentrations at NIST IAQ Test House from Operation of Portable Electric Generators in Attached Garage – Interim Report|url=https://www.nist.gov/manuscript-publication-search.cfm?pub_id=907771|publisher=United States National Institute of Standards and Technology|accessdate=2012-04-18|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130224044200/http://nist.gov/manuscript-publication-search.cfm?pub_id=907771|archivedate=2013-02-24|df=}} Exposure typically occurs when equipment is used in buildings or semi-enclosed spaces. Riding in the back of [[pickup trucks]] has led to poisoning in children.{{cite journal|vauthors=Hampson NB, Norkool DM |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning in children riding in the back of pickup trucks|journal=JAMA|volume=267|issue=4|pages=538–40|date=January 1992|pmid=1370334|doi=10.1001/jama.267.4.538|url=}} Idling automobiles with the exhaust pipe blocked by snow has led to the poisoning of car occupants.{{cite journal|author=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)|title=Carbon monoxide poisonings associated with snow-obstructed vehicle exhaust systems—Philadelphia and New York City, January 1996|journal=MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report|volume=45|issue=1|pages=1–3|date=January 1996|pmid=8531914|url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00039929.htm|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170624015949/https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00039929.htm|archivedate=2017-06-24|df=}} Any perforation between the exhaust manifold and shroud can result in exhaust gases reaching the cabin. Generators and propulsion engines on boats, especially houseboats, has resulted in fatal carbon monoxide exposures.{{cite journal |author=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)|title=Houseboat-associated carbon monoxide poisonings on Lake Powell—Arizona and Utah, 2000|journal=MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report|volume=49|issue=49|pages=1105–1108|date=December 2000|pmid=11917924|url=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/coboating/|title=NIOSH Carbon Monoxide Dangers in Boating|accessdate=2007-10-15|publisher=United States National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013113132/http://cdc.gov/niosh/topics/coboating/|archivedate=2007-10-13|df=}} Poisoning may also occur following the use of a self-contained underwater breathing apparatus (SCUBA) due to faulty [[diving air compressor]]s.{{cite journal|vauthors=Austin CC, Ecobichon DJ, Dussault G, Tirado C |title=Carbon monoxide and water vapor contamination of compressed breathing air for firefighters and divers|journal=Journal of Toxicology and Environmental Health|volume=52|issue=5|pages=403–23|date=December 1997|pmid=9388533|doi=10.1080/00984109708984073}} In caves carbon monoxide can build up in enclosed chambers due to the presence of decomposing organic matter.{{cite book |last=Dart| first= RC |chapter= |title=Medical toxicology |publisher=Williams & Wilkins| location=Philadelphia |year=2004|page=1169| isbn=0781728452}} In coal mines incomplete combustion may occur during explosions resulting in the production of [[afterdamp]]. The gas is up to 3% CO and may be fatal after just a single breath. Following an explosion in a colliery, adjacent interconnected mines may become dangerous due to the afterdamp leaking from mine to mine. Such an incident followed the [[Trimdon Grange]] explosion which killed men in the [[Kelloe]] mine.{{citation | url = http://www.healeyhero.co.uk/rescue/pits/Trimdon_Grange/Trimdon3.htm#top | title = Trimdon Grange, Durham. 16th February 1882 | accessdate = 22 May 2012 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170330072644/http://www.healeyhero.co.uk/rescue/pits/Trimdon_Grange/Trimdon3.htm#top | archivedate = 30 March 2017 | df = }} Another source of poisoning is exposure to the organic solvent [[dichloromethane]], found in some [[paint stripper]]s,{{cite journal|last=van Veen|first=MP|author2=Fortezza F |author3=Spaans E |author4=Mensinga TT |title=Non-professional paint stripping, model prediction and experimental validation of indoor dichloromethane levels|journal=Indoor Air|year=2002|volume=12|issue=2|pages=92–97|doi=10.1034/j.1600-0668.2002.01109.x|pmid=12216472}} as the metabolism of dichloromethane produces carbon monoxide.{{cite journal|vauthors=Kubic VL, Anders MW |title=Metabolism of dihalomethanes to carbon monoxide. II. In vitro studies|journal=Drug Metabolism and Disposition|date=March 1975|pages=104–12|volume=3|issue=2|pmid=236156}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Dueñas A, Felipe S, Ruiz-Mambrilla M, Martín-Escudero JC, García-Calvo C |title=CO poisoning caused by inhalation of CH3Cl contained in personal defense spray|journal=The American Journal of Emergency Medicine|volume=18|issue=1|pages=120–21|date=January 2000|pmid=10674554|doi=10.1016/S0735-6757(00)90070-6}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Varon J, Marik PE, Fromm RE, Gueler A |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning: A review for clinicians|journal= [[The Journal of Emergency Medicine]] |year=1999|pages=87–93|volume=17|issue=1|pmid=9950394|doi=10.1016/S0736-4679(98)00128-0}} == Pathophysiology == The precise mechanisms by which the effects of carbon monoxide are induced upon bodily systems, are complex and not yet fully understood. Known mechanisms include carbon monoxide binding to [[hemoglobin]], [[myoglobin]] and [[mitochondrial]] [[cytochrome oxidase]] and restricting oxygen supply, and carbon monoxide causing [[brain]] [[lipid peroxidation]].{{cite journal|author=Bateman DN|title=Carbon Monoxide|journal=Medicine|volume=31|issue=10|page=233|date=October 2003|doi=10.1383/medc.31.10.41.27810}} === Hemoglobin === [[File:Hemoglobin saturation curve.svg|thumb|Carbon monoxide shifts the oxygen-dissociation curve to the left.]] Carbon monoxide has a higher diffusion coefficient compared to oxygen, and the only enzyme in the human body that produces carbon monoxide is [[heme oxygenase]], which is located in all cells and breaks down [[heme]]. Under normal conditions, carbon monoxide levels in the [[Blood plasma|plasma]] are approximately 0 [[Millimeter of mercury|mmHg]] because it has a higher diffusion coefficient and the body easily gets rid of any CO made.{{cite book|title=USMLE Step 1 Lecture Notes: Physiology|year=2011|author=Dunn, Robert B.|author2=Kudrath, W. |author3=Passo, SS |author4=Wilson, LB|pages=167–68|chapter=7-3}} When CO is not ventilated it binds to hemoglobin, which is the principal oxygen-carrying compound in blood; this produces a compound known as [[carboxyhemoglobin]]. The traditional belief is that carbon monoxide toxicity arises from the formation of carboxyhemoglobin, which decreases the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood and inhibits the transport, delivery, and utilization of oxygen by the body. The affinity between hemoglobin and carbon monoxide is approximately 230 times stronger than the affinity between hemoglobin and oxygen so hemoglobin binds to carbon monoxide in preference to oxygen.{{cite journal|vauthors=Townsend CL, Maynard RL |title=Effects on health of prolonged exposure to low concentrations of carbon monoxide|journal=Occupational and Environmental Medicine|volume=59|issue=10|pages=708–11|date=October 2002|pmid=12356933|pmc=1740215|doi=10.1136/oem.59.10.708|url=}}{{cite journal|author=Haldane J|title=The action of carbonic oxide on man|journal=The Journal of Physiology|year=1895|pages=430–62|volume=18|url=http://jp.physoc.org/content/18/5-6/430.full.pdf|pmid=16992272|issue=5–6|pmc=1514663|doi=10.1113/jphysiol.1895.sp000578|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708152937/http://jp.physoc.org/content/18/5-6/430.full.pdf|archivedate=2011-07-08|df=}} Hemoglobin is a [[Tetrameric protein|tetramer]] with four oxygen binding sites. The binding of carbon monoxide at one of these sites increases the oxygen affinity of the remaining three sites, which causes the hemoglobin molecule to retain oxygen that would otherwise be delivered to the tissue.{{cite journal|vauthors=Gorman D, Drewry A, Huang YL, Sames C |title=The clinical toxicology of carbon monoxide|journal=Toxicology|date=May 2003|pages=25–38|volume=187|issue=1|pmid=12679050|doi=10.1016/S0300-483X(03)00005-2}} This situation is described as carbon monoxide shifting the [[oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve|oxygen dissociation curve]] to the left. Because of the increased affinity between hemoglobin and oxygen during carbon monoxide poisoning, little oxygen will actually be released in the tissues. This causes hypoxic tissue injury. Hemoglobin acquires a bright red color when converted into carboxyhemoglobin, so poisoned cadavers and even commercial meats treated with carbon monoxide acquire an unnatural reddish hue. === Myoglobin === Carbon monoxide also binds to the [[hemeprotein]] [[myoglobin]]. It has a high affinity for myoglobin, about 60 times greater than that of oxygen. Carbon monoxide bound to myoglobin may impair its ability to utilize oxygen. This causes reduced [[cardiac output]] and [[hypotension]], which may result in [[brain ischemia]]. A delayed return of symptoms have been reported. This results following a recurrence of increased carboxyhemoglobin levels; this effect may be due to a late release of carbon monoxide from myoglobin, which subsequently binds to hemoglobin. === Cytochrome oxidase === Another mechanism involves effects on the mitochondrial respiratory enzyme chain that is responsible for effective tissue utilization of oxygen. Carbon monoxide binds to [[cytochrome oxidase]] with less affinity than oxygen, so it is possible that it requires significant intracellular hypoxia before binding.{{cite journal |vauthors=Gorman DF, Runciman WB |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning |journal=Anaesthesia and Intensive Care |volume=19 |issue=4 |pages=506–11 |date=November 1991 |pmid=1750629 |doi= |url=}} This binding interferes with aerobic metabolism and efficient [[adenosine triphosphate]] synthesis. Cells respond by switching to [[anaerobic metabolism]], causing [[Hypoxia (medical)|anoxia]], [[lactic acidosis]], and eventual cell death.{{cite journal|vauthors=Alonso JR, Cardellach F, Lopez S, Casademont J, Miro O |title=Carbon monoxide specifically inhibits cytochrome c oxidase of human mitochondrial respiratory chain|journal=Pharmacology & Toxicology|date=September 2003|pages=142–46|volume=93|issue=3|pmid=12969439|doi=10.1034/j.1600-0773.2003.930306.x}} The rate of [[Dissociation (chemistry)|dissociation]] between carbon monoxide and cytochrome oxidase is slow, causing a relatively prolonged impairment of [[oxidative metabolism]]. === Central nervous system effects === The mechanism that is thought to have a significant influence on delayed effects involves formed blood cells and chemical mediators, which cause brain [[lipid peroxidation]] (degradation of unsaturated fatty acids). Carbon monoxide causes [[endothelial]] cell and platelet release of [[nitric oxide]], and the formation of [[oxygen free radicals]] including [[peroxynitrite]]. In the brain this causes further mitochondrial dysfunction, [[capillary]] leakage, [[leukocyte]] sequestration, and [[apoptosis]].{{cite journal|author=Blumenthal I|title=Carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine|date=June 2001|pages=270–72|volume=94|issue=6|pmid=11387414|url=http://www.jrsm.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=11387414|format=Free full text|pmc=1281520|doi=10.1177/014107680109400604}} The result of these effects is [[lipid peroxidation]], which causes delayed reversible [[Demyelinating disease|demyelinization]] of [[white matter]] in the central nervous system known as [[Grinker myelinopathy]], which can lead to [[edema]] and [[necrosis]] within the brain. This brain damage occurs mainly during the recovery period. This may result in cognitive defects, especially affecting memory and learning, and movement disorders. These disorders are typically related to damage to the cerebral [[white matter]] and [[basal ganglia]].{{cite journal|vauthors=Fan HC, Wang AC, Lo CP, Chang KP, Chen SJ |title=Damage of cerebellar white matter due to carbon monoxide poisoning: a case report|journal=[[The American Journal of Emergency Medicine]]|volume=27|issue=6|pages=757.e5–e7|date=July 2009|pmid=19751650|doi=10.1016/j.ajem.2008.10.021}} Hallmark pathological changes following poisoning are bilateral necrosis of the white matter, [[globus pallidus]], [[cerebellum]], [[hippocampus]] and the [[cerebral cortex]].{{cite journal|vauthors=Prockop LD, Chichkova RI |title=Carbon monoxide intoxication: an updated review|journal=Journal of the Neurological Sciences|date=Nov 2007|pages=122–30|volume=262|issue=1–2|pmid=17720201|doi=10.1016/j.jns.2007.06.037}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Fukuhara M, Abe I, Matsumura K, Kaseda S, Yamashita Y, Shida K, Kawashima H, Fujishima M |title=Circadian variations of blood pressure in patients with sequelae of carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=American Journal of Hypertension |volume=9|issue=4 Part 1|pages=300–05|date=April 1996|pmid=8722431|doi=10.1016/0895-7061(95)00342-8}} === Pregnancy === Carbon monoxide poisoning in pregnant women may cause severe adverse [[fetus|fetal]] effects. Poisoning causes fetal tissue [[Hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]] by decreasing the release of maternal oxygen to the fetus. Carbon monoxide also crosses the [[placenta]] and combines with [[fetal hemoglobin]], causing more direct fetal tissue hypoxia. Additionally, fetal hemoglobin has a 10 to 15% higher affinity for carbon monoxide than adult hemoglobin, causing more severe poisoning in the fetus than in the adult. Elimination of carbon monoxide is slower in the fetus, leading to an accumulation of the toxic chemical.{{cite journal|vauthors=Greingor JL, Tosi JM, Ruhlmann S, Aussedat M |title=Acute carbon monoxide intoxication during pregnancy. One case report and review of the literature|journal=Emergency Medicine Journal|volume=18|issue=5|pages=399–401|date=September 2001|pmid=11559621|pmc=1725677|doi=10.1136/emj.18.5.399|url=http://emj.bmj.com/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=11559621}} The level of fetal morbidity and mortality in acute carbon monoxide poisoning is significant, so despite mild maternal poisoning or following maternal recovery, severe fetal poisoning or death may still occur.{{cite journal|vauthors=Farrow JR, Davis GJ, Roy TM, McCloud LC, Nichols GR |title=Fetal death due to nonlethal maternal carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Journal of Forensic Sciences|volume=35|issue=6|pages=1448–52|date=November 1990|pmid=2262778}} == Diagnosis == [[File:Co monitor.JPG|thumb|Finger tip [[carboxyhemoglobin]] saturation monitor (SpCO%). Note: This is not the same as a pulse oximeter (SpO2%), although some models (such as this one) do measure both the oxygen and carbon monoxide saturation.]] [[File:Breath CO Monitor.jpg|thumb|Breath CO monitor displaying carbon monoxide concentration of an exhaled breath sample (in ppm) with its corresponding percent concentration of carboxyhemoglobin.]] As many symptoms of carbon monoxide poisoning also occur with many other types of poisonings and infections (such as the flu), the diagnosis is often difficult.{{cite journal|vauthors=Bennetto L, Powter L, Scolding NJ |title=Accidental carbon monoxide poisoning presenting without a history of exposure: A case report|journal=Journal of Medical Case Reports|volume=2|issue=1|page=118|date=April 2008|pmid=18430228|doi=10.1186/1752-1947-2-118|pmc=2390579}} A history of potential carbon monoxide exposure, such as being exposed to a residential fire, may suggest poisoning, but the diagnosis is confirmed by measuring the levels of carbon monoxide in the blood. This can be determined by measuring the amount of [[carboxyhemoglobin]] compared to the amount of [[hemoglobin]] in the blood. The ratio of carboxyhemoglobin to hemoglobin molecules in an average person may be up to 5%, although cigarette smokers who smoke two packs per day may have levels up to 9%.{{cite book|veditors=Ford MD, Delaney KA, Ling LJ, Erickson T |title=Clinical Toxicology|year=2001|page=1046|publisher=WB Saunders Company|isbn=0721654851}} In symptomatic poisoned people they are often in the 10–30% range, while persons who die may have postmortem blood levels of 30–90%.Sato K, Tamaki K, Hattori H, et al. Determination of total hemoglobin in forensic blood samples with special reference to carboxyhemoglobin analysis. For. Sci. Int. 48: 89–96, 1990.R. Baselt, ''Disposition of Toxic Drugs and Chemicals in Man'', 8th edition, Biomedical Publications, Foster City, CA, 2008, pp. 237–41. As people may continue to experience significant symptoms of CO poisoning long after their blood carboxyhemoglobin concentration has returned to normal, presenting to examination with a normal carboxyhemoglobin level (which may happen in late states of poisoning) does not rule out poisoning.{{cite journal|vauthors=Keleş A, Demircan A, Kurtoğlu G |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning: how many patients do we miss?|journal=European Journal of Emergency Medicine |volume=15|issue=3|pages=154–57|date=June 2008|pmid=18460956|doi=10.1097/MEJ.0b013e3282efd519}} ===Measuring=== Carbon monoxide may be quantitated in blood using [[spectrophotometry|spectrophotometric]] methods or [[chromatography|chromatographic techniques]] in order to confirm a diagnosis of poisoning in a person or to assist in the forensic investigation of a case of fatal exposure. A [[CO-oximeter]] can be used to determine carboxyhemoglobin levels.{{cite journal|vauthors=Rodkey FL, Hill TA, Pitts LL, Robertson RF |title=Spectrophotometric measurement of carboxyhemoglobin and methemoglobin in blood|journal=Clinical Chemistry|volume=25|issue=8|pages=1388–93|date=August 1979|pmid=455674|doi=|url=http://www.clinchem.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=455674|accessdate=2009-07-17}}{{cite journal|vauthors=Rees PJ, Chilvers C, Clark TJ |title=Evaluation of methods used to estimate inhaled dose of carbon monoxide|journal=Thorax|volume=35|issue=1|pages=47–51|date=January 1980|pmid=7361284|pmc=471219|doi= 10.1136/thx.35.1.47|url=http://thorax.bmj.com/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=7361284}} Pulse [[CO-oximeter]]s estimate carboxyhemoglobin with a non-invasive finger clip similar to a [[pulse oximeter]].{{cite journal|vauthors=Coulange M, Barthelemy A, Hug F, Thierry AL, De Haro L|title=Reliability of new pulse CO-oximeter in victims of carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=Undersea & Hyperbaric Medicine|volume=35|issue=2|pages=107–11|date=March 2008|pmid=18500075|doi=|url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/8084|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110625021038/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/8084|archivedate=2011-06-25|df=}} These devices function by passing various wavelengths of light through the fingertip and measuring the light absorption of the different types of hemoglobin in the capillaries.{{Cite journal|last = Maisel | first = William | authorlink = |author2=Roger J. Lewis | title = Noninvasive Measurement of Carboxyhemoglobin: How Accurate is Accurate Enough? | journal = Annals of Emergency Medicine | volume = 56 | issue = 4 | pages = 389–91 | publisher = | location = Boston, MA | year = 2010 | doi=10.1016/j.annemergmed.2010.05.025}} The use of a regular [[pulse oximeter]] is not effective in the diagnosis of carbon monoxide poisoning as people with carbon monoxide poisoning may have a normal [[oxygen saturation]] level on a pulse oximeter.{{cite journal|vauthors=Vegfors M, Lennmarken C |title=Carboxyhaemoglobinaemia and pulse oximetry|journal=British Journal of Anaesthesia|volume=66|issue=5|pages=625–626|date=May 1991|pmid=2031826|doi=10.1093/bja/66.5.625}} This is due to the carboxyhemoglobin being misrepresented as oxyhemoglobin.{{cite journal|vauthors=Barker SJ, Tremper KK |title=The effect of carbon monoxide inhalation on pulse oximetry and transcutaneous PO2|journal=Anesthesiology|volume=66|issue=5|pages=677–79|date=May 1987|pmid=3578881|doi=10.1097/00000542-198705000-00014}} [[Carbon monoxide breath monitor|Breath CO monitoring]] offers an alternative to pulse CO-oximetry. Carboxyhemoglobin levels have been shown to have a strong correlation with breath CO concentration.{{cite journal|first=M.|last=Jarvis|year=1986|title=Low cost carbon monoxide monitors in smoking assessment|journal=Thorax|pages=886–87|doi=10.1136/thx.41.11.886|volume=41|issue=11|pmc=460516}}{{cite journal|first=Nicholas|last=Wald|year=1981|title=Carbon monoxide in breath in relation to smoking and carboxyhaemoglobin levels|journal=Thorax|pages=366–69|doi=10.1136/thx.36.5.366|pmid=7314006|pmc=471511|volume=36|issue=5}} However, many of these devices require the user to inhale deeply and hold their breath to allow the CO in the blood to escape into the lung before the measurement can be made. As this is not possible in people who are unresponsive, these devices may not appropriate for use in on-scene emergency care detection of CO poisoning. === Differential diagnosis === There are many conditions to be considered in the differential diagnosis of carbon monoxide poisoning.{{cite journal |vauthors=Kao LW, Nañagas KA |title=Toxicity associated with carbon monoxide |journal=Clinics in Laboratory Medicine |volume=26 |issue=1 |pages=99–125 |date=March 2006 |pmid=16567227 |doi=10.1016/j.cll.2006.01.005}}{{cite web | last =Shochat | first =Guy N | title =Toxicity, Carbon Monoxide | publisher =[[emedicine]] | date =17 February 2009 | url =http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/819987-overview | accessdate =2009-04-27 | deadurl =no | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20090309072832/http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/819987-overview | archivedate =9 March 2009 | df = }} The earliest symptoms, especially from low level exposures, are often non-specific and readily confused with other illnesses, typically [[influenza|flu-like viral syndromes]], [[clinical depression|depression]], [[chronic fatigue syndrome]], [[chest pain]], and [[migraine]] or other headaches.{{cite journal | vauthors=Ilano AL, Raffin TA | title=Management of carbon monoxide poisoning | journal=Chest | date=Jan 1990 | pages=165–69 | volume=97 | issue=1 | pmid=2403894 | doi=10.1378/chest.97.1.165 }} Carbon monoxide has been called a "great mimicker" due to the presentation of poisoning being diverse and nonspecific. Other conditions included in the differential diagnosis include [[acute respiratory distress syndrome]], [[altitude sickness]], [[lactic acidosis]], [[diabetic ketoacidosis]], [[meningitis]], [[methemoglobinemia]], or [[Opioid overdose|opioid]] or toxic alcohol poisoning. == Prevention == [[File:CO DETECTOR (cropped).JPG|thumb|Carbon monoxide detector connected to a North American power outlet]] === Detectors === [[File:COMonitor.jpg|thumb|A carbon monoxide monitor clipped to the uniform of a paramedic]] Prevention remains a vital [[public health]] issue, requiring public education on the safe operation of appliances, heaters, fireplaces, and internal-combustion engines, as well as increased emphasis on the installation of [[carbon monoxide detector]]s.{{cite journal|vauthors=Ernst A, Zibrak JD |title=Carbon monoxide poisoning|journal=The New England Journal of Medicine|volume=339|issue=22|pages=1603–08|date=November 1998|pmid=9828249|doi=10.1056/NEJM199811263392206|url=http://content.nejm.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=short&pmid=9828249&promo=ONFLNS19}} Carbon monoxide is tasteless and odourless, and therefore can not be detected by visual cues or smell.{{cite journal |title=Compressed breathing air – the potential for evil from within |vauthors=Millar IL, Mouldey PG |year=2008 |volume=38 |issue=2 |pages=145–51 |journal=Diving and Hyperbaric Medicine |publisher=[[South Pacific Underwater Medicine Society]] |url=http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/7964 |accessdate=2013-04-14 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101225063245/http://archive.rubicon-foundation.org/7964 |archivedate=2010-12-25 |df= |pmid=22692708 }} The United States [[Consumer Product Safety Commission]] has stated, "carbon monoxide detectors are as important to home safety as smoke detectors are," and recommends each home have at least one carbon monoxide detector, and preferably one on each level of the building. These devices, which are relatively inexpensive and widely available, are either battery- or AC-powered, with or without battery backup.{{cite web|last=Lipinski|first=Edward R|title=Keeping Watch on Carbon Monoxide|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 14, 1999|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/02/14/nyregion/home-clinic-keeping-watch-on-carbon-monoxide.html|accessdate=2009-09-09|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110623100533/http://www.nytimes.com/1999/02/14/nyregion/home-clinic-keeping-watch-on-carbon-monoxide.html|archivedate=June 23, 2011|df=}} In buildings, carbon monoxide detectors are usually installed around heaters and other equipment. If a relatively high level of carbon monoxide is detected, the device sounds an alarm, giving people the chance to evacuate and ventilate the building.{{cite journal |vauthors=Krenzelok EP, Roth R, Full R |title=Carbon monoxide ... the silent killer with an audible solution |journal=The American Journal of Emergency Medicine |date=September 1996 |pages=484–86 |volume=14 |issue=5 |pmid=8765117 |doi=10.1016/S0735-6757(96)90159-X }}{{cite journal |vauthors=Yoon SS, Macdonald SC, Parrish RG |title=Deaths from unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning and potential for prevention with carbon monoxide detectors |journal=JAMA |date=March 1998 |pages=685–87 |volume=279 |issue=9 |pmid=9496987 |doi=10.1001/jama.279.9.685 }} Unlike [[smoke detector]]s, carbon monoxide detectors do not need to be placed near ceiling level. The use of carbon monoxide detectors has been standardized in many areas. In the US, NFPA 720-2009,{{cite book|title=NFPA 720: Standard for the Installation of Carbon Monoxide (CO) Detection and Warning Equipment|publisher=National Fire Protection Agency|location=Quincy, MA|year=2009|pages=|isbn=}} the carbon monoxide detector guidelines published by the [[National Fire Protection Association]], mandates the placement of carbon monoxide detectors/alarms on every level of the residence, including the basement, in addition to outside sleeping areas. In new homes, AC-powered detectors must have battery backup and be interconnected to ensure early warning of occupants at all levels. NFPA 720-2009 is the first national carbon monoxide standard to address devices in non-residential buildings. These guidelines, which now pertain to schools, healthcare centers, nursing homes and other non-residential buildings, include three main points: :1. A secondary power supply (battery backup) must operate all carbon monoxide notification appliances for at least 12 hours, :2. Detectors must be on the ceiling in the same room as permanently installed fuel-burning appliances, and :3. Detectors must be located on every habitable level and in every [[HVAC]] zone of the building. Gas organizations will often recommend to get gas appliances serviced at least once a year.{{cite web|title=Gas Safety in the Home |publisher=UK Gas Safe Register |accessdate=2013-05-27 |url=http://www.gassaferegister.co.uk/advice/being_gas_safe.aspx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130502012946/http://gassaferegister.co.uk/advice/being_gas_safe.aspx |archivedate=2013-05-02 |df= }} === Legal requirements === The NFPA standard is not necessarily enforced by law. As of April 2006, the US state of Massachusetts requires detectors to be present in all residences with potential CO sources, regardless of building age and whether they are owner-occupied or rented.{{cite web|url=http://www.malegislature.gov/Laws/GeneralLaws/PartI/TitleXX/Chapter148/Section26F1~2|title=MGL Ch. 148 §28F{{frac|1|2}} – Nicole's Law, effective March 31, 2006|work=malegislature.gov|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121230154311/http://www.malegislature.gov/Laws/GeneralLaws/PartI/TitleXX/Chapter148/Section26F1~2|archivedate=December 30, 2012|df=}} This is enforced by municipal inspectors, and was inspired by the death of 7-year-old Nicole Garofalo in 2005 due to snow blocking a home heating vent.{{cite web |url=http://www.lawlib.state.ma.us/subject/about/carbonmonoxide.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-02-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130305145343/http://www.lawlib.state.ma.us/subject/about/carbonmonoxide.html |archivedate=2013-03-05 |df= }} Other jurisdictions may have no requirement or only mandate detectors for new construction or at time of sale. Despite similar deaths in vehicles with clogged exhaust pipes (for example in the [[Northeastern United States blizzard of 1978]] and [[February 2013 nor'easter]]) and the commercial availability of the equipment, there is no legal requirement for automotive CO detectors.{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} ===World Health Organization recommendations=== The following guideline values (ppm values rounded) and periods of time-weighted average exposures have been determined in such a way that the carboxyhaemoglobin (COHb) level of 2.5% is not exceeded, even when a normal subject engages in light or moderate exercise: * 100 mg/m3 (87 ppm) for 15 min * 60 mg/m3 (52 ppm) for 30 min * 30 mg/m3 (26 ppm) for 1 h * 10 mg/m3 (9 ppm) for 8 h For indoor air quality 7 mg/m3 (6 ppm) for 24 h (so as not to exceed 2% COHb for chronic exposure) == Treatment == {| class="wikitable" style = "float: right; margin-left:15px; text-align:center;" |+ Time to remove 50% carboxy hemoglobin{{cite book|last1=Mathieu|first1=Daniel|title=Handbook on Hyperbaric Medicine|date=2006|publisher=Springer|location=[New York]|isbn=978-1402043765|edition=Online-Ausg.}} ! Oxygen pressure О2 ! Time |- |21% oxygen at normal atmospheric pressure (fresh air) | 5 hours 20 min |- |100% oxygen at normal atmospheric pressure (non-rebreather oxygen mask) | 1 hours 20 min |- |100% Hyperbaric oxygen (3 atmospheres absolute) | 23 min |} Initial treatment for carbon monoxide poisoning is to immediately remove the person from the exposure without endangering further people. Those who are unconscious may require [[Cardiopulmonary resuscitation|CPR]] on site. Administering [[oxygen]] via [[non-rebreather mask]] shortens the [[Biological half-life|half-life]] of carbon monoxide from 320 minutes, when breathing normal air, to only 80 minutes.
