{{Other uses}} {{Original research|date=March 2010}} A '''happy ending''' is an ending of the [[Plot (narrative)|plot]] of a work of [[fiction]] in which almost everything turns out for the best for the [[protagonists]], their [[sidekick]]s, and almost everyone except the [[villain]]s.
In storylines where the protagonists are in physical [[Risk|danger]], a happy ending mainly consists of their survival and successful completion of the [[quest]] or mission; where there is no physical danger, a happy ending may be lovers [[Consummation|consummating]] their love despite various factors which may have thwarted it. A considerable number of storylines combine both situations. In [[Steven Spielberg]]'s version of "[[War of the Worlds (2005 film)|War of the Worlds]]", the happy ending consists of three distinct elements: The protagonists all survive the countless perils of their journey; humanity as a whole survives the alien invasion; ''and'' the protagonist father regains the respect of his estranged children. The plot is so constructed that all three are needed for the audience's feeling of satisfaction in the end.
A happy ending is epitomized in the standard [[fairy tale]] ending phrase, "'''happily ever after'''" or "and they lived happily ever after". (''[[One Thousand and One Nights]]'' has the more restrained formula "they lived happily until there came to them the One who Destroys all Happiness" (i.e. Death); likewise, the Russian versions of fairy tales typically end with "they lived long and happily, and died together on the same day".) Satisfactory happy endings are happy for the reader as well, in that the characters he or she sympathizes with are rewarded. However, this can also serve as an open path for a possible sequel. For example, in the 1977 film ''[[Star Wars (film)|Star Wars]]'', [[Luke Skywalker]] defeats the [[Galactic Empire (Star Wars)|Galactic Empire]] by destroying the [[Death Star]]; however, the story's happy ending has consequences that follow in ''[[The Empire Strikes Back]]''. The concept of a permanent happy ending is specifically brought up in the [[Stephen King]] fantasy/fairy tale novel ''[[The Eyes of the Dragon]]'' which has a standard good ending for the genre, but simply states that "there were good days and bad days" afterwards.
==Features== A happy ending only requires that the main characters be all right. Millions of innocent background characters can die, but as long as the characters that the reader/viewer/audience cares about survive, it can still be a happy ending. [[Roger Ebert]] comments in his review of [[Roland Emmerich]]'s ''[[The Day After Tomorrow]]'': "Billions of people may have died, but at least the major characters have survived. Los Angeles is leveled by multiple tornadoes, New York is buried under ice and snow, the United Kingdom is flash-frozen, and lots of the Northern Hemisphere is wiped out for good measure. Thank god that Jack, Sam, Laura, Jason and Dr. Lucy Hall survive, along with Dr. Hall's little [[cancer]] patient."<ref>[http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20040528/REVIEWS/405280303/1023 Ebert's review of ''The Day After Tomorrow'']</ref>
==Examples== ===William Shakespeare=== The presence of a happy ending is one of the key points that distinguish [[melodrama]] from [[tragedy]]. In certain periods, the endings of traditional tragedies such as ''[[Macbeth]]'' or ''[[Oedipus Rex]]'', in which most of the major characters end up dead, disfigured, or discountenanced, have been actively disliked. In the Seventeenth Century, the Irish author [[Nahum Tate]] sought to improve [[William Shakespeare]]'s ''[[King Lear]]'' in [[The History of King Lear|his own heavily modified version]] in which Lear survives and Cordelia marries Edgar. Tate's version dominated performances for a century and a half, Shakespeare's original nearly forgotten. Both [[David Garrick]] and [[John Philip Kemble]], while taking up some of Shakespeare's original text, kept Tate's happy ending. [[Edmund Kean]] played ''King Lear'' with its tragic ending in 1823, but failed and reverted to Tate's crowd-pleaser after only three performances. Only in 1838 did [[William Macready]] at Covent Garden successfully restore Shakespeare's original tragic end – [[Helena Faucit|Helen Faucit]]'s final appearance as Cordelia, dead in her father's arms, became one of the most iconic of Victorian images and the play's tragic end was finally accepted by the general public. Most subsequent critics have not found Tate's amendments an improvement, and welcomed the restoration of Shakespeare's original. Happy endings have also been fastened – equally, with no lasting success – to ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' and ''[[Othello]]''.
There is no universally accepted definition of what a happy ending is; such definitions can considerably vary with time and cultural differences. An interpretation of ''[[The Merchant of Venice]]''{{'}}s forced conversion of [[Shylock]] to Christianity is that it was intended as a happy ending. As a Christian, Shylock could no longer impose interest, undoing his schemes in the play and ending the rivalry between him and Antonio, but more important, contemporary audiences would see becoming a Christian as a means to save his soul (cf. [[Epistle to the Romans|Romans]] 11:15). In later times, Jews (and non-Jewish opponents of anti-Semitism) strongly objected to that ending, regarding it as depicting a victory for injustice and oppression and as pandering to the audience's prejudices.
===Don Juan===
Most interpretations of the [[legend]] of [[Don Juan]] end with the protagonist [[Rake (stock character)|rake]] being dragged off to [[Hell]], in just retribution for his many sins (for example, the ending of [[Mozart]]'s ''[[Don Giovanni]]''). However, [[José Zorrilla]] - whose 1844 [[Play (theatre)|play]] ''[[Don Juan Tenorio]]'' is the version most well-known in the Spanish-speaking world - believed that a story should never end sadly, and must always have a happy ending. In Zorrilla's depiction, Don Juan is saved at the last moment from the flames of Hell by the selfless pure love of Doña Inés, a woman whom he wronged but who forgave him; she had made a deal with God to offer her own blameless soul on behalf of Don Juan's - thus redeeming Don Juan and taking him with her to [[Paradise]].
===Novels=== A ''[[The Times|Times]]'' review of ''[[The Spy Who Came in from the Cold]]'' strongly criticized [[John le Carré]] for failing to provide a happy ending, and gave unequivocal reasons why in the reviewer's opinion (shared by many others) such an ending is needed: "''The hero must triumph over his enemies, as surely as [[Jack and the Beanstalk|Jack]] must kill the giant in the nursery tale. If the giant kills Jack, we have missed the whole point of the story.''"<ref>''[[The Times]]'', September 13, 1968.</ref>
[[George Bernard Shaw]] had to wage an uphill struggle against audiences, as well as some critics, persistently demanding that his "[[Pygmalion (play)#Ending|Pygmalion]]" have a happy ending, i.e. that Professor Higgins and Eliza Doolitle would ultimately get married.<ref>Evans, T.F. (ed.) (1997). ''George Bernard Shaw (The Critical Heritage Series).'' {{ISBN|0-415-15953-9}}, pp. 223–30.</ref><ref>"From the Point of View of A Playwright," by Bernard Shaw, collected in ''Herbert Beerbohm Tree, Some Memories of Him and His Art, Collected by Max Beerbohm'' (1919). London: Hutchinson. [https://archive.org/details/herbertbeerbohmt00beer Versions at Text Archive] [https://archive.org/about/about.php Internet Archive]<!--Retrieved from http://archive.org November 2[[3, 2009.--></ref> To Shaw's great chagrin, [[Herbert Beerbohm Tree]] who presented the play in London's [[West End theatre|West End]] in 1914 had sweetened the ending and told Shaw: "My ending makes money; you ought to be grateful. Your ending is damnable; you ought to be shot."<ref>Shaw, Bernard, edited by Dan H. Laurence. Collected Letters vol. III: 1911–1925.</ref> The irritated Shaw added a postscript essay, "'What Happened Afterwards",<ref>Shaw, G.B. (1916). ''Pygmalion''. New York: Brentano. [http://www.bartleby.com/138/6.html Sequel: What Happened Afterwards.] [http://www.bartleby.com/sv/welcome.html Bartleby: Great Books Online.]</ref> to the 1916 print edition, for inclusion with subsequent editions, in which he explained precisely why in his view it was impossible for the story to end with Higgins and Eliza getting married. Nevertheless, audiences continued wanting a happy ending also for later adaptations such as the musical and film "[[My Fair Lady]]".
===Hollywood films===
In numerous cases, [[Hollywood]] studios adapting literary works into film added a happy ending which did not appear in the original. * [[Mary Shelley]]'s 1818 novel, ''[[Frankenstein]]'', ended with the deaths of [[Victor Frankenstein]] and [[Elizabeth Lavenza]]. In the [[Frankenstein (1931 film)|1931 film adaption]] they survive and marry. * [[C. S. Forester]]'s 1935 novel ''[[The African Queen (novel)|The African Queen]]'' has a British couple, stranded in Africa during the [[First World War]], hatch a plot to sink a German gunboat; they make an enormous, dedicated struggle, with boundless effort and sacrifice, but at the last moment their quest ends with failure and futility. In the [[The African Queen (film)|1951 film adaptation]] they succeed, and get to see the German boat sink (just in time to save them from being hanged by the Germans). * [[Truman Capote]]'s [[1958 in literature|1958]] [[novella]] ''[[Breakfast at Tiffany's (novella)|Breakfast at Tiffany's]]'' ended with the main character, Holly Golightly, going her own solitary way and disappearing from the male protagonist's life. In the 1961 [[Breakfast at Tiffany's (film)| film made on its base]] she finally accepts the love he offers her and the film ends with their warmly embracing, oblivious of a pouring rain. * [[Hans Christian Andersen]]'s [[fairy tale]] ''[[The Little Mermaid]]'' ends with the protagonist mermaid making a noble sacrifice, resigned to seeing her beloved prince marrying another woman. In the 1989 [[The Little Mermaid (1989 film)| Disney adaptation]], the mermaid does get to happily marry her prince. Disney later added [[The Little Mermaid II: Return to the Sea |a sequel]], obviously impossible for the Andersen original, focused on the child born of that marriage.

5× Region 8-AA COY | coaching_records = }} '''Danny Hugh Freeze Jr.'''{{cite web|title=Nicholls coaching search nets 42 applicants |url=http://www.houmatoday.com/news/20091224/nicholls-coaching-search-nets-42-applicants|work=Houma Today|accessdate=December 14, 2013 |date=December 24, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131215023851/http://www.houmatoday.com/article/20091224/ARTICLES/912239867 |archivedate=December 15, 2013|deadurl=no}} (born September 27, 1969) is an [[American football]] coach. He is currently the Offensive Coordinator for the University of Tennessee. He is the former head coach of the [[University of Mississippi]]. Freeze served as the head football coach at [[Lambuth University]] from 2008 to 2009 and at [[Arkansas State University]] in 2011. He was previously a successful high school football coach at [[Briarcrest Christian School]] in [[Memphis, Tennessee]], where he coached [[Michael Oher]] and [[Greg Hardy]]. He would later follow both of them to the University of Mississippi. ==Early life== Freeze attended [[Senatobia Municipal School District|Senatobia High School]] and the [[University of Southern Mississippi]], from which he graduated in 1992 with a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in [[mathematics]] and a minor in coaching and [[sports administration]].[http://www.astateredwolves.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=7200&ATCLID=204944063 Hugh Freeze Bio], Arkansas State University, retrieved December 16, 2010. ==Coaching career== ===Briarcrest Christian School=== In 1992, Freeze joined the staff at [[Briarcrest Christian School]] in [[Memphis, Tennessee]], as the football team's [[offensive coordinator]] and [[defensive backs coach]]. Freeze also served as dean of students.{{cite news|last1=Giannotto |first1=Mike|title=At Briarcrest Christian School, Hugh Freeze's legacy is everywhere |url=https://www.commercialappeal.com/story/sports/2017/07/24/briarcrest-christian-school-hugh-freezes-legacy-everywhere/506677001/ |work=The Commercial Appeal|date=July 24, 2017}} In 1995, he was promoted to head coach. Freeze ran the no huddle spread offense and led his team to the state championship twice, in 2002 and 2004, and the regional championship each year from 1995 to 1998 and in 2001 and 2002. He received Region 8-AA Coach of the Year honors five times and Associated Press Coach of the Year honors six times. In ten years at Briarcrest, Freeze was 94–30 as head coach (.785 winning percentage) and 126–37 overall.{{cite web |url=http://www.briarcrest.com/page.aspx?pid=821 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=September 25, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101213161936/http://briarcrest.com/page.aspx?pid=821 |archivedate=December 13, 2010}} Freeze was depicted in [[The Blind Side: Evolution of a Game|the book]] and motion picture ''[[The Blind Side (film)|The Blind Side]]'', about one of his former players, current free agent offensive tackle [[Michael Oher]].[http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/40483873/ns/sports-college_football/ Oher's HS Coach Gets Top Job at Arkansas State], NBC Sports, December 2, 2010. While at Briarcrest Christian School, Freeze also coached the girls basketball team from 1992 to 2004, and actually had more success in this role, with an overall record of 305–63 (.829 winning percentage), seven straight championship appearances, and four championships.{{cite web|url=http://mobile.nytimes.com/2014/10/22/sports/ncaafootball/hugh-freeze-coach-at-ole-miss-follows-an-unlikely-blueprint.html|title=Hugh Freeze, Coach at Ole Miss, Follows an Unlikely Blueprint|accessdate=August 25, 2018}} Following his dismissal from [[Ole Miss]], some former students alleged that Freeze had engaged in inappropriate conduct with female students while at Briarcrest.{{cite news|last1=Heim|first1=Mark|title=Hugh Freeze stories emerge from former female students at Briarcrest Christian|url=https://www.al.com/sports/index.ssf/2017/07/hugh_freeze_stories_emerge_fro.html|work=AL.com|date=July 31, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Peter|first1=Josh|title=Who is Hugh Freeze? Conflicting views of former Ole Miss coach emerge |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/ncaaf/2017/07/29/who-hugh-freeze-conflicting-views-former-ole-miss-coach-emerge/522705001/ |work=USA Today|date=July 29, 2017}} Freeze has denied the allegation and the school has stated it is unaware of any sexual improprieties involving Freeze during his tenure at the school. ===Ole Miss=== In 2005, the [[University of Mississippi]] hired Freeze as an assistant athletic director for football external affairs. The following season, he became the [[tight ends coach]] and [[recruiting coordinator]], positions he held through 2007. After [[2007 Ole Miss Rebels football team|that season]], he replaced head coach [[Ed Orgeron]] on an interim basis before the hiring of [[Houston Nutt]]. Freeze interviewed for the offensive coordinator position with Nutt,{{cite web |url=http://www.wtok.com/sports/headlines/13665882.html |title=Nutt Has Long List for New OC |date=January 9, 2008 |work=WTOK.com |accessdate=December 4, 2013}} a position that eventually went to [[Kent Austin]]. ===Lambuth=== In January 2008, [[Lambuth University]], a member of the [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics]] (NAIA), named Freeze its head coach.[http://www.lambutheagles.com/article/252.php Hugh Freeze Named Lambuth University Head Football Coach], Lambuth University, January 19, 2008. In 2008, he led Lambuth to an 8–4 record and a first round loss in the NAIA playoffs, marking their first appearance in the playoffs since 2004 under then head coach Vic Wallace. He was considered for the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga's head coaching position following the 2008 season, but remained at Lambuth University for another season and compiled a 20–5 overall record, and defeating opponents 41–17 on average. In 2009, he led the Eagles to their best regular season record in school history with an unblemished 11–0 mark. Lambuth advanced to the second round of the NAIA playoffs for first time in 11 years—having won one game before suffering elimination to finish 12–1 as the sixth-ranked team in the NAIA. ===Arkansas State=== In 2010, he joined the staff at [[Arkansas State Red Wolves football|Arkansas State]] as offensive coordinator after a brief stint as offensive coordinator at [[San Jose State University]] under [[Mike MacIntyre]]. The Red Wolves finished with a 4–8 record, but their offensive rankings jumped from 95th in total offense and 90th in scoring offense in the [[NCAA]] [[Division I FBS]] to 43rd and 46th, respectively. The Red Wolves' offense broke nine school records including total plays (856), first downs (262), pass attempts (438), pass completions (266), completion percentage (.607), passing yards (3,057), passing yards per game (254.8), and passing touchdowns (23). The Red Wolves' offense averaged 403.4 yards per game, eclipsing over 300 yards all 12 times it took the field for the first time in the history of the program. A-State posted at least 400 yards of total offense in seven games during the 2010 campaign, the most ever as an NCAA FBS member, all in his first year as offensive coordinator. After [[2010 Arkansas State Red Wolves football team|the season]], Freeze was promoted to replace head coach [[Steve Roberts (American football)|Steve Roberts]].[http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=5875374&campaign=rss&source=NCFHeadlines Hugh Freeze hired at Arkansas St.], ESPN, December 2, 2010. In 2011, his only season as head coach at Arkansas State, he led the Red Wolves to a 10–2 record and their first Sun Belt Conference title since 2005. The Red Wolves' offense averaged 447.8 ypg (28th nationally, 1st in Sun Belt Conference) including 293.6 ypg passing and 154.2 ypg rushing.{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/schools/arkansas-state/2011.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=September 26, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121109125126/http://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/schools/arkansas-state/2011.html |archivedate=November 9, 2012}} Freeze left Arkansas State before the Arkansas State's appearance in the [[GoDaddy.com Bowl]] following the season. ===Ole Miss=== On December 5, 2011, Freeze was announced as the 37th head coach of the University of Mississippi. During the press conference to introduce Freeze as the head coach, he stated that he wanted to "retire at Ole Miss." He was signed to a four-year contract with an annual salary of $1.5 million plus incentives up to $2.5 million.{{cite news |title=Hugh Freeze is Rebels' new coach |url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/7319777/hugh-freeze-mississippi-rebels-emotional-accepting-coaching-job |agency=Associated Press |publisher=ESPN.com |date=December 5, 2011 |accessdate=December 5, 2011}} In his first season at Ole Miss, Freeze led the Rebels to a 6–6 record in the regular season, making Ole Miss bowl eligible for the first time since 2009 with a 41–24 victory over Mississippi State in the [[Egg Bowl]]. His Rebels accepted a bid to play in the BBVA Compass Bowl in Birmingham, Alabama, on January 5, 2013. They beat the University of Pittsburgh 38–17 to finish 7–6. Freeze received national attention on [[National Signing Day]] 2013 as Ole Miss brought in the fifth ranked recruiting class in the country.{{cite web |url=http://insider.espn.go.com/college-sports/football/recruiting/classrankings?class=2013 |title=2013 Football Class Rankings |work=ESPN.com |accessdate=December 4, 2013}} Freeze won the 2014 Grant Teaff Coach of the Year award by the Fellowship of Christian Athletes.{{cite web |url=http://www.fca.org/2014/01/13/hugh-freeze-named-grant-teaff-coach-of-the-year/ |title=Hugh Freeze named coach of the year by Fellowship of Christian Athletes |work=FCA.org |accessdate=January 13, 2014}} During Freeze's third season at Ole Miss, he led the Rebels to a 7–0 start, the program's best start since the [[Johnny Vaught]] era. By October, they had risen as high as third in the nation, their highest ranking at that late stage in the season in almost half a century. They ultimately finished 9–3, only the third time since Vaught's tenure that Ole Miss has won that many games in the regular season. That netted them an appearance in the [[2014 Peach Bowl]]–their first major bowl appearance since the [[1970 Sugar Bowl]], and easily the biggest bowl they had attended since Vaught's tenure. On September 19, 2015, Freeze's Rebels beat Alabama, 43–37, in [[Tuscaloosa, Alabama]], making Freeze only the third head coach, along with [[Les Miles]] and [[Steve Spurrier]], to defeat a [[Nick Saban]]-coached team in back-to-back years (Michigan's Lloyd Carr beat Saban's Michigan State Spartans in three consecutive years, '96–'98). The victory catapulted the Rebels to #3 in the AP rankings. They went on to tally their second straight nine-win season, and garnered a berth in the [[2016 Sugar Bowl]], where they won 48–20 over [[Oklahoma State Cowboys football|Oklahoma State]]. They finished ninth in the AP Poll and 10th in the Coaches' Poll—their first top-10 finishes in a final poll since 1969. In January 2016, the NCAA charged Ole Miss with numerous recruiting violations. An investigation turned up evidence that Ole Miss employees and boosters arranged numerous "impermissible benefits" for players, such as car loans and cash. At least one recruit was suspected of getting help on his college entrance exam.{{cite news|url=https://www.sbnation.com/college-football/2017/2/22/14703296/ole-miss-ncaa-allegations-list-2017|title=The updated list of 21 NCAA allegations against Ole Miss football|author=Morgan Moriarty|publisher=[[SB Nation]] |date= February 22, 2017}} The investigation reopened soon after star offensive tackle [[Laremy Tunsil]] admitted taking money from one of Freeze's assistants.{{cite news |title=Laremy Tunsil says he took money from coach at Ole Miss |work=ESPN |date=April 28, 2016 |url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/15424437/2016-nfl-draft-laremy-tunsil-admits-taking-cash-ole-miss-rebels-coach}} In February 2017—three months after suffering its first losing season since the year Freeze arrived—Ole Miss withdrew from bowl consideration for the upcoming season. The move came on the same day that the NCAA sent an updated notice of allegations charging the Rebels with eight additional violations. Most seriously, it accused Freeze of not monitoring his assistants, and also accused Ole Miss of not properly controlling the program. On July 13, 2017, Freeze's predecessor, [[Houston Nutt]], sued Ole Miss for defamation, contending that Freeze and school officials falsely blamed him for the violations. As part of discovery for the lawsuit, Nutt's attorneys filed a [[Freedom of Information Act]] request for calls Freeze made on his university-issued cell phone during January 2016. Nutt's attorneys contended that Freeze and others at Ole Miss leaked information to the press as part of an effort to smear their client.http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/sns-bc-fbc--mississippi-freezes-downfall-20170721-story.html While reviewing those records, Nutt's attorneys discovered a call to a number associated with a female [[escort service]], and alerted Ole Miss officials about it. Freeze claimed it was a misdialed number.{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/ncaaf/sec/2017/07/20/ole-miss-coach-hugh-freeze-called-number-tied-escort-service/498056001/|title=Ole Miss football coach Hugh Freeze made call to number tied to escort service|accessdate=August 25, 2018}} School officials investigated, and discovered what they later described as "a concerning pattern" of similar calls dating back to shortly after he arrived in Oxford. On July 20, chancellor [[Jeff Vitter]] and athletic director [[Ross Bjork]] gave Freeze an ultimatum: resign or be fired for violating the [[morals clause]] of his contract. Freeze opted to resign; offensive coordinator [[Matt Luke (American football)|Matt Luke]] was named interim coach.{{Cite news |url=http://www.espn.com/college-football/story/_/id/20117453/hugh-freeze-ole-miss-rebels-resigns-escort-service-calls-cited |title=Ole Miss coach Hugh Freeze resigns; escort-service calls cited {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Jessica McClure | image = | birth_name = Jessica McClure | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1986|3|26}} | birth_place = [[Midland, Texas]], U.S. | known_for = falling into a well at 18 months | other_names = Jessica McClure Morales | spouse = {{marriage|Daniel Morales|2006}} | children = 2 }} '''Jessica McClure Morales''' (born March 26, 1986) became famous on October 14, 1987, at the age of 18 months after she fell into a [[water well|well]] in her aunt's backyard in [[Midland, Texas]]. Between that day and October 16, rescuers worked for 56 hours to free her from the {{convert|8|in|cm|adj=on|spell=in}} [[casing (borehole)|well casing]] {{convert|22|ft|m}} below the ground.{{cite web|url=http://abc13.com/30-years-ago-rescue-of-baby-jessica-from-the-well/1555516/|title=30 years ago: Rescue of 'Baby Jessica' from the well|date=October 14, 2016|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/18-month-old-girl-saved-1987-article-1.2386153|title=Jessica McClure, an 18-month-old girl, is saved after 58 long hours trapped in a well in 1987 - NY Daily News|publisher=}} The story gained worldwide attention (leading to some criticism as a [[media circus]]), and later became the subject of a 1989 [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] television movie ''[[Everybody's Baby: The Rescue of Jessica McClure]]''. == Rescue == McClure's rescue proved to be a much more difficult ordeal than was first anticipated. Within hours of beginning the emergency procedure, the Midland Fire and Police Departments devised a plan that involved drilling another shaft parallel to the well and then drilling a tunnel at a right angle across to it. Enlisting the help of a variety of local (often out-of-work) oil-drillers, the Midland officials had hoped to free McClure in minutes. However, the first workers to arrive on the scene found their tools barely adequate to penetrate the hard rock around the well. It took about six hours to drill the shaft and longer to drill the tunnel, because the [[jackhammer]]s used were designed for drilling downward, rather than sideways. A mining engineer eventually arrived to help supervise and coordinate the rescue effort. TV viewers watched as paramedics and rescuers, drilling experts and contractors worked tirelessly to save the baby's life. Meanwhile, they were reassured when they heard Jessica singing “[[Winnie the Pooh (song)|Winnie the Pooh]]” from deep in the well. As long as she was still singing, they knew she was still alive.{{cite news|last1=Higgins|first1=Darla|title=Baby Jessica 30 Years Later: 'My Life Is a Miracle'|url=http://people.com/human-interest/baby-jessica-30-years-later-my-life-is-a-miracle/|accessdate=15 October 2017|website=People.com|date=31 May 2017|quote=Television viewers watched as hundreds of paramedics, rescuers, drilling experts and contractors feverishly worked to save the baby's life. Meanwhile, they were reassured when they heard Jessica singing “[[Winnie the Pooh (song)|Winnie the Pooh]]” from deep in the well. As long as she was singing, she was still alive.}} Forty-five hours after McClure fell into the well, the shaft and tunnel were finally completed. The relatively new technology of [[Water jet cutter|waterjet cutting]], used to cut through the hard rock surrounding the well, was a vital part of the rescue.{{cite book|title=Business Week|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p-0dAQAAMAAJ|year=1989|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.}}{{cite book|author=National Science Foundation (U.S.)|title=Annual report for fiscal year ...|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7EEc-gZcTJkC|year=1987|publisher=The Foundation}} Ron Short, a muscular roofing contractor who was born without collar bones because of [[cleidocranial dysostosis]] and so could collapse his shoulders to work in cramped corners, arrived at the site and offered to go down the shaft. They considered his offer, but did not use it.{{cite news |first= J. Michael |last= Kennedy |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1987-10-17/news/mn-3702_1_jessica-mcclure |title=Jessica Makes It to Safety—After 58 1/2 Hours |work= [[Los Angeles Times]] |date=October 17, 1987 |accessdate=November 24, 2010}}{{cite journal|first=Ronald W. |last=Scott |url=http://www.jospt.org/members/getfile.asp?id=3740 |format=PDF |title=Cleidocranial Dysplasia: An Enigma Among Anomalies |journal=The Journal of Orthopaedic and Sports Physical Therapy |date=November 1988 |volume=10 |issue=5 |pages=184–8 |issn=0190-6011 |accessdate=November 24, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404192505/http://www.jospt.org/members/getfile.asp?id=3740 |archivedate=April 4, 2012 |df= }} One report said that he helped to clear tunneling debris away.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcuniversalarchives.com/nbcuni/clip/5112434055_s02.do|title=Home - News, Entertainment, World Events Video - NBCUniversal Archives|website=NBCUniversal Archives|accessdate=May 26, 2018}} Midland Fire Department paramedic Robert O'Donnell was ultimately able to inch his way into the tunnel and wrestle McClure free from the confines of the well, handing her to fellow paramedic Steve Forbes, who carried her up to safety. == Media coverage == [[CNN]] was on the scene with around-the-clock coverage of the rescue effort. This massive media saturation of the ordeal prompted then-President [[Ronald Reagan]] to state that "everybody in America became godmothers and godfathers of Jessica while this was going on." From the beginning and throughout the incident, the switchboard of local media outlet [[KMID-TV]] was flooded with telephone calls from news organizations and private individuals around the world, seeking the latest information on rescue efforts. In some cases, they shared their own insight into this and similar incidents. In 1988, McClure and her parents appeared on ''[[Live with Regis and Kathie Lee]]'' to talk about the incident. The photograph of McClure being rescued fetched the [[1988 Pulitzer Prize|1988]] [[Pulitzer Prize for Breaking News Photography|Pulitzer Prize for Spot News Photography]] to Scott Shaw of the ''[[Odessa American]]''.{{cite web |author= Staff |url=http://www.pulitzer.org/awards/1988 |title= 1988 Winners and Finalists |work= The Pulitzer Prizes |publisher= Columbia University |date= |accessdate=November 24, 2010}} ABC made a television movie of the story in 1989, ''[[Everybody's Baby: The Rescue of Jessica McClure]]'', starring [[Patty Duke]] and [[Beau Bridges]]. It featured many participants in the actual rescue and its coverage as extras. On May 30, 2007, ''[[USA Today]]'' ranked McClure number 22 on its list of "25 lives of indelible impact."{{cite web|last=Koch |first=Wendy |url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/top25-people.htm |title=Lives of Indelible Impact |work= [[USA Today]] |date=May 29, 2007 |accessdate=November 24, 2010}} == Aftermath == [[File:President George H.W. Bush holds Jessica McClure in the Roosevelt Room at the White House (1989-07-19).jpg|thumb|President [[George H. W. Bush]] meeting McClure at the White House in 1989]] Following McClure's rescue on October 16, 1987, surgeons had to amputate a toe due to [[gangrene]] from loss of circulation while she was in the well. She also has a scar on her forehead where her head rubbed against the well casing. She had 15 surgeries over the years and has no first-hand memory of the event.{{cite web |url= http://www9.comcast.net/articles/news-national/20110325/US.Baby.Jessica/ |last= Blaney |first= Betsy |title= Baby Jessica turns 25, gains access to trust fund |work= Xfinity News |agency= [[Associated Press]] |date= March 25, 2011 |accessdate= March 25, 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110326215656/http://www.comcast.net/articles/news-national/20110325/US.Baby.Jessica/ |archivedate= March 26, 2011}} Her parents divorced a few years after the rescue. Paramedic Robert O'Donnell, battling [[posttraumatic stress disorder]] as a result of the arduous rescue effort and struggling to cope with the abrupt decline of the fame and recognition that had been lavished on him following his heroic act, committed suicide in 1995.{{cite news |last1=Belkin|first1=Lisa |title=Death on the CNN Curve |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/23/magazine/death-on-the-cnn-curve.html |accessdate=July 18, 2017 |work=The New York Times |date=July 23, 1995}} McClure graduated from [[Greenwood Independent School District|Greenwood High School]], in a small community near Midland, in May 2004. On January 28, 2006, nineteen-year-old McClure married Daniel Morales at [[Church of Christ]] in [[Notrees, Texas]], about 40 miles from Midland. They met at a day care center where she worked with his sister.{{cite news |last= Celizic |first= Mike |url= http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/19165433/ |title= Baby Jessica 20 Years Later |publisher= [[MSNBC]] |date= November 6, 2007 |accessdate= November 24, 2010}} They have two children, a boy born 2007 and a girl born 2009.{{cite news|url=https://people.com/human-interest/baby-jessica-on-the-30-year-anniversary-of-her-rescue-from-a-well-her-life-as-a-wife-and-mom/|title=Baby Jessica On the 30 Year Anniversary of Her Rescue from a Well: Her Life as a Wife and Mom|first=Steve|last=Helling|date=October 16, 2017|publisher=[[People magazine]]}} When McClure turned 25 on March 26, 2011, she received a [[escrow|trust fund]] of donations worth up to $800,000. Her father said she had discussed setting up a trust fund for the college education of her children. It had earlier helped in the purchase of her present home, which is less than {{convert|2|mi|km|spell=in}} from the site of the incident. == In popular culture == * Footage of McClure's rescue appeared in [[Michael Jackson]]'s music video for the song "[[Man in the Mirror]]".{{YouTube|PivWY9wn5ps|Michael Jackson - Man In The Mirror (Official Video); 3:45}} * [[Lucie Brock-Broido]]'s long narrative poem "Jessica from the Well" (1988) tells the story from McClure's point of view, describing her as having a basic understanding of the physical and mythic elements of her situation. It has been reprinted numerous times.{{cite book |first= Lucie |last= Brock-Broido |chapter= Jessica, from the Well |title= A Hunger |location= New York |publisher=Knopf |year= 1988 |isbn= 978-0-394-56337-4 }} * A 1990 Indian movie, ''[[Malootty]]'', was based on the incident.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}} *''[[The Simpsons]]'' episode "[[Radio Bart]]" (1992) revolved around a similar incident.http://www.popmatters.com/column/119350- the-simpsons-radio-bart-9-january-1992-part-2/{{cite web|url=http://www.gabbinggeek.com/2016/03/30/simpsons-did-it-radio-bart/|title=Simpsons Did It!: "Radio Bart"|date=March 30, 2016|website=Gabbinggeek.com|accessdate=May 26, 2018}} * In the 1995 film ''[[12 Monkeys]]'', a heavily fictionalized version of the Jessica McClure story plays out in TV and radio newscasts throughout the film. The entire nation is transfixed as a nine-year-old boy named "Ricky Newman" is believed to have fallen down a well in Fresno, California. Rescuers similarly dig a second well parallel to the one they think he is in, but James Cole (Bruce Willis) tells Kathryn Railly (Madeleine Stowe) that the boy is, in fact, hiding in a barn. He is later proven right. He knows this because he is a time traveler and remembers the events from when he was a child. * In 2010, [[blues]] musician [[Charlie Musselwhite]] released an album titled ''The Well''. In the title song he credits McClure's ordeal for inspiring him to quit drinking.{{cite news |url= http://leisureblogs.chicagotribune.com/turn_it_up/2010/09/how-baby-jessica-saved-blues-great-charlie-musselwhite.html |title= How 'Baby Jessica' Saved Blues Great Charlie Musselwhite |first= Greg |last= Kot |work= [[Chicago Tribune]] |date= September 28, 2010 |accessdate= June 4, 2013}} * A 2012 episode of ''[[American Dad!]]'' titled "[[National Treasure 4: Baby Franny: She's Doing Well: The Hole Story]]" featured a storyline which was essentially a parody of McClure's story, including a story revolving around the misfortunes of her rescuer.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}} *In a ''[[Modern Family]]'' episode "Heavy is the Head" (2017) Cam reveals he fell into a well the same day as McClure, but she got all the press.{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/tv/cams-bitter-rivalry-with-baby-jessica-on-modern-family-070139822.html|title=Cam's Bitter Rivalry With Baby Jessica on 'Modern Family'|website=Yahho.com|accessdate=May 26, 2018}} == See also == * [[Floyd Collins]], an early case of "man trapped in cave" that received similar coverage in 1925 * [[2010 Copiapó mining accident]], a similarly highly covered event * [[Kathy Fiscus]], a child who died after falling into a well in 1949 * [[Alfredo Rampi]], a child who died after falling into a well in 1981 * [[Tikki Tikki Tembo]] * ''[[The Well (1951 film)|The Well]]'', 1951 film in which a little girl falls into a well and the town unites to save her by drilling a parallel shaft == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb name|id=1532391|name=Jessica McClure}} *"[http://www.vqronline.org/articles/1988/summer/brockbroido-jessica-from-well/ Jessica, from the Well]" poem by Lucie Brock-Broido {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McClure, Jessica}} [[Category:1986 births]] [[Category:1987 in Texas]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Accidents]] [[Category:People from Midland, Texas]]

'''Katie Martin''' (born '''Katie Louise Van Veen''' on January 8, 1972) is an American [[consultant]] in [[Environmentally friendly|eco-friendly]] special events, [[floral design]], and green events and life styles.
== Personal life == {{unreferenced|date=July 2018|section}} Martin was born in [[Washington, DC]]. She graduated from the [[University of Maryland, College Park]], in 1994 with a BS in [[accounting]]. She has one son and is married to Neftali Miguel Vasquez Perez.
== Features and interviews == * [[Style Network]]'s show ''[[Whose Wedding Is It Anyway]]?''<ref>[http://video.tvguide.com/ID/544864 ''TV Guide.'' Whose Wedding Is It Anyway?]</ref> * [[Washingtonian magazine|''Washingtonian'' magazine]]<ref>[http://www.washingtonian.com/chats/shopping/10456.html Washingtonian.com: Wedding Planner Chat with Katie Martin]</ref> * ''[[Washington Post]]''<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/06/22/AR2005062201475.html ''Washington Post''. "Down the Aisle, Into the Melting Pot."]</ref> *''Elegant Bride'' magazine<ref>[http://www.brides.com/planning/flowers/feature/article/6399#top Brides.com. Expert design.]</ref> *''Floral Management'' magazine<ref>[http://www.eleganceandsimplicity.com/press.htm ''Floral Management''. "The Chosen One." (Select #48)]</ref> *[[WUSA (TV)|WUSA]] (Washington, DC, CBS affiliate)<ref>[http://www.wusa9.com/news/news_article.aspx?storyid=33016 WUSA. Local Couple Prepares for 9/11 Wedding.]</ref> *[[WTOP-FM|WTOP]] (Washington, DC, talk-radio station)<ref>[http://www.eleganceandsimplicity.com/images/press/09-10%20a%20720%20Sept%2011th%20Wedding.mp3 WTOP]</ref> *[[TBD TV]] (Washington, DC, cable television network)<ref>http://www.letstalklive.tv/n_videoplayer.cfm?video=ltlmartin0129.wmv&id=105</ref>
Martin’s work also has been showcased in ''DC Modern Luxury Magazine'', ''Flower Magazine'', ''Catering Magazine'', ''Florists' Review'', ''Washington Woman'', ''Grace Ormonde'', ''Upscale Magazine'', ''Bride & Bloom'', ''Modern Bride'', ''My Day Magazine'', ''The Knot'', ''Engaged Magazine'', and ''La Bella Bride''.
Founded in 1998, Martin's wedding and event planning company, Elegance & Simplicity Wedding & Event Designers, Inc. (located in [[Bethesda, Maryland]] with a sister office in [[Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic]]) has planned about 3,500 [[wedding]]s worldwide.<ref name="washingtonian.com">[http://www.washingtonian.com/blogarticles/weddings/bridalparty/10469.html Washingtonian.com. Bridal Party Chat: Ask an Ecofriendly Planner]</ref> Martin also founded and runs Green Life DC, a consulting firm that helps individuals, families, events and businesses be more environmentally friendly.
Currently Martin is writing a book on [[green wedding]]s.<ref name="washingtonian.com"/>

[[File:Lets Do It Mediterranean action in Cyprus.jpg|thumb|Let's Do It! Mediterranean 2014 action in Cyprus]] [[File:Let's Do It! Afghanistan.jpg|thumb|Let's Do It! Afghanistan 2015]] '''Let's Do It! World''' is a global civic movement that started from [[Estonia]], asking people worldwide to join a series of local, national and regional clean-up events. Among other projects, it is the founder of '''[[World Cleanup Day]]'''.
The Let's Do It! movement was first conceived in Estonia in year 2008, where a country clean-up action called '''[[Let's Do It 2008|Let's do it!]]''' (in [[Estonian language|Estonian]]: "Teeme Ära!") cleaned up 10,000 tons of illegal waste by more than 50,000 volunteers in one day. Following Estonia's lead many countries also started their own country clean-up events.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinkitimes.fi/htimes/domestic-news/general/15176-finland-gets-spring-cleaning.html |title=Finland gets spring cleaning |date= |accessdate=2012-01-02}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web |url=http://blog.heifer.org/2011/07/ukrainian-participants-clean-up-their.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120715071118/http://blog.heifer.org/2011/07/ukrainian-participants-clean-up-their.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-15 |title=Ukrainian Participants Clean Up Their Village |date= |accessdate=2012-01-02 }}</ref> In 2011 a new initiative called Let's do it! World was started with the aim of promoting massive clean-ups from 24 March 2012 till 15 September 2012.<ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/cyberguided-cleanup-hopes-to-sweep-globe-2281350.html |title=Cyber-guided clean-up hopes to sweep globe |date= 2011-05-09|accessdate=2012-01-02 |location=London |work=The Independent}}</ref> After a successful World Cleanup 2012 project the next bigger goal is to have [[World Cleanup Day]] in 2018.
Today, the movement has grown into a network of 113 countries. All together, 14 million participants have been engaged in movement's activities.<ref>Kalev Leetaru: [https://www.forbes.com/sites/kalevleetaru/2016/07/30/how-pokemon-and-location-based-augmented-reality-could-save-the-planet/#4f804c9766cc "How Pokémon And Location-Based Augmented Reality Could Save The Planet"] Forbes, 2016-07-30</ref>
Let's Do It! World is an accredited member of the [[United Nations Environment Programme|United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP)]].
Since 2017, the movement uses [[W sign]] aka Three Fingers Up as a symbol.
{{TOC limit|limit=3}}
==The origins of the massive cleanup movement== On the 3rd of May 2008 over 50,000 people came out of their homes to clean up Estonia, the rest followed the process via all the media channels. That's 4% out of a population of 1,3 million - which would equal 15,3 million in the USA or 57 million in India. The idea spread from Estonia to the whole Europe and beyond.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20100125-anti-garbage-campaigners-plan-mass-internet-led-clean |title=Anti-garbage campaigners plan mass Internet-led clean up |date= |accessdate=2012-01-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100129054219/http://www.france24.com/en/20100125-anti-garbage-campaigners-plan-mass-internet-led-clean |archivedate=2010-01-29 |df= }}</ref> Next spring, in 2009, Latvia and Lithuania cleaned their countries with more than 250,000 people participating and have done it henceforth for three years, engaging more people each year.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hCNrezFwQUYGj2rJNJJ75ENwcDgQ |title=AFP: Massive clean-up drive in Latvia, Lithuania |date= |accessdate=2012-01-02}}</ref> On 20 March 2010 Portugal cleaned their country with 200,000 people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euronews.net/2010/03/20/massive-countryside-clean-up-in-portugal/ |title=Massive countryside clean-up in Portugal |date= |accessdate=2012-01-02}}</ref> [[Let's Clean Slovenia in One Day!|Slovenia followed shortly]], breaking all records with 270,000 people (which is 13% of the overall population of the country) taking part in the action.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/video/?/video/international/2010/05/03/wv.clean.up.slovenia.cnn |title=CNN: Big clean up in Slovenia |date= |accessdate=2012-01-02}}</ref> In the beginning of June the same year, Kyiv, the capital of Ukraine was cleaned.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> By the end of 2011 more than 2.5 million people have participated in Let’s Do It! cleanup actions in 16 countries – Estonia, India, Slovenia, Serbia, Finland, Romania, Latvia, Lithuania, Portugal, Bulgaria, Moldova, Ukraine, Cambodia, Russia, Hungary and Brazil.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.letsdoitworld.org/statistics |title=Let's Do It! World country statistics |date= |accessdate=2011-12-09}}</ref>
==World Cleanup 2012== In 2012, starting from 24 March until 25 September, a series of cleanups happened around the globe, on all continents, bringing together millions of volunteers in 96 countries.<ref name=autogenerated2 /> The action was initiated on 24 March 2012 by [[Let's Clean Slovenia|volunteers in Slovenia]] and [[Portugal]].
To bring together doers and initiators and share existing experience – Let's Do It! teams were organizing workshops and regional gatherings, introducing the World Cleanup 2012 around the world. Each group or organisation was leading the cleanup action in their country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.letsdoitworld.org/countries |title=Let's Do It! World countries |date= |accessdate=2011-12-09}}</ref>
<gallery> Cleanup in Armenia.jpg|[[Armenia]] Let's Do It! Bangladesh 2012.jpg|[[Bangladesh]] Slovenska vojska v okoljski akciji Očistimo Slovenijo 2012 (4).jpg|[[Slovenia]] </gallery> ==World Cleanup actions until 2018== After a successful World Cleanup 2012 project, the network set more ambitious goals. During the [https://web.archive.org/web/20140310071639/http://www.letsdoitworld.org/news/civic-leaders-40-countries-gather-kosovo-erase-massive-waste-problem Let's Do It! Clean World Conference held in Prishtina], Kosovo on the 6th-9th of February 2014, it was agreed, that the aim of the global movement is to clean up the whole World from illegally dumped solid waste and to then keep the planet clean. To reach the essential transformation in the global society, the leaders of country cleanups set the ambitious goal to involve 380 million people by 2018. According to Let's Do It! World, this is around 5% of the world’s population and is estimated to be the amount to create a lasting change.
==Biggest cleanup actions== [[File:Let's Do It! Ukraine 2015.jpg|thumb|Let's Do It! Ukraine 2015]] The most massive cleanup actions (data: October 2014) within the movement have happened in Slovenia, Bulgaria, Latvia, Lithuania, Kosovo and in Albania.
In 2012, 289,000 '''Slovenians''' came out of the homes and cleaned up the entire country in just one day. This is 14% of the country's population.
In 2013, 375,000 cleaned up the country in '''Bulgaria''' in a one-day country cleanup action (13,9% of country's population).
In 2012, 210,000 people (10% of country's population) cleaned up '''Latvia''' from illegal waste in just one day.
In 2013, a massive civic cleanup action also took place in '''Kosovo''', bringing together 132,000 people (7% of the population) and in the same year, Albania also had a massive cleanup action, uniting 147,000 people (5,25%) to clean up the country in just one day.
In 2015, 250,000 people (8,6% of country's population) cleaned up '''Lithuania''' from illegal waste in one day.
In 2015, over 500,000 people participated in Let's Do It! actions in '''Ukraine''' cleaning up illegal dump-sites around the country.
==World Cleanup 2018== {{Main|World Cleanup Day}}
Around 15 millions people in 158 countries took part on the World Clean Up Day, the 15th of September 2018.

A pamphlet with the title ''A short narrative of the horrid massacre in Boston, perpetrated in the evening of the fifth day of March, 1770, by soldiers of the 29th regiment, which with the 14th regiment were then quartered there; with some observations on the state of things prior to that catastrophe'' was printed still in 1770. page.title: List of fan conventions by date of founding

revision.text:
The '''list of modern [[fan conventions]]''' for various genres of entertainment extends to the first conventions held in the 1930s.
Some fan historians claim that the 1936 Philadelphia Science Fiction Conference, a.k.a. [[Philcon]], was the first science fiction convention ever held. Others, such as [[Fred Patten]] and [[Rob Hansen]], make this claim for the January 1937 event in [[Leeds]], [[England]],<ref>Mike Glyer. [http://www.fiawol.org.uk/fanstuff/THEN%20Archive/1937conFirst.htm "THE FIRST EVER CONVENTION,"] ''The Story So Far'' (Worldcon, 1987).</ref> organized by the Leeds Science Fiction League, which was specifically organised as a conference, with a program and speakers. Out of this came the first incarnation of the [[British Science Fiction Association]].
While a few conventions were created in various parts of the world within the period between 1935-1960, the number of convention establishments increased slightly in the 1960s and then increased dramatically in the 1970s, with many of the largest conventions in the modern era being established during the latter decade. Impeti for further establishment of local fan conventions include:
* The return of superhero characters and franchises during the [[Silver Age of Comic Books]] (1956-1970) * science fiction adaptations for television serials (e.g., ''[[Star Trek]]'') in the 1960s-1970s * the growth of role-playing (in the 1970s and 1980s) as a genre of tabletop, live-action and eventually video/computer gaming, which not only inspired roleplay of favorite characters in full-body costumes but also inspired existing franchises to adapt their themes for said methods of gaming * the growth in home taping (starting with VHS in the late 1970s) of television broadcasts, including popular serials. * the growth of computerized communication, including the Internet and Internet-dependent applications in the 1980s and 1990s.

{{Expand list|date=August 2008}} [[Image:I-45 & Louetta Rita Evacuation.jpg|thumb|Evacuees fleeing [[Hurricane Rita]] in Texas, United States]]
This '''list of mass evacuations''' includes [[emergency evacuation]]s of a large number of people in a short period of time. An emergency evacuation is the movement of persons from a dangerous place due to the threat or occurrence of a disastrous event whether from [[Natural disaster|natural]] or [[Man-made hazards|man made]] causes or as the result of [[war]].
==Ancient times== * 480 BC – The [[Greece|Greek]] officer of state and navy commander [[Themistocles]] ordered the evacuation of [[Athens]] as a strategic countermeasure to the approaching [[Achaemenid Empire|Persian]] army, leading to 100,000 inhabitants being displaced in the late summer.
==1st century== * 60–61 – [[Boudica's uprising]] results in the mass evacuation of numerous [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] settlements in [[Great Britain|Britain]]. * 79 – Eruption of [[Mount Vesuvius]] causes evacuation of [[Pompeii]] and surrounding areas.
==5th century== * 410 – [[Sack of Rome (410)|Sack of Rome]] by [[Visigoths]] under [[Alaric I]]. Many [[Rome, Italy|Romans]] were either taken captive and sold into slavery or later fled the devastated city.
==13th century== * 1237–1293 – [[Mongol invasion of Europe]]: Many thousands in eastern [[Europe]] are displaced or flee before each of several Mongol expeditions.
==14th century== * 1351 – Peak of the [[Black Death]], which [[Consequences of the Black Death|led to mass evacuations]] in numerous cities, ports, and villages in Asia, Europe, and [[Egypt]].
==19th century== * 1836 – The [[Battle of the Alamo|Fall of the Alamo]] results in a mass evacuation of American, [[Mexico|Mexican]], [[Tejano]], and [[Texian]] persons in what is known as the [[Runaway Scrape]].
==20th century== [[File:Evacuees from Mount Pinatubo board the USS Abraham Lincoln.jpg|thumb|U.S. military dependents board {{USS|Abraham Lincoln|CVN-72}} in the aftermath of the [[Mount Pinatubo#The 1991 eruption|1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo]].]] * April 20, 1906 – The resultant fire of the [[1906 San Francisco earthquake]] leads to evacuation by sea of 20,000 refugees.<ref>{{cite web|title=Timeline of the San Francisco Earthquake|publisher=The Virtual Museum of the City of San Francisco|url=http://www.sfmuseum.org/hist10/06timeline.html|accessdate=2007-10-25 }}</ref> * Between March 1937 and October 1938, nearly 3,000 children were evacuated from [[Spain]] to the [[Soviet Union]]. Most of the children were from the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque Country]], [[Asturias]], and [[Cantabria]]. On June 12, 1937 over 1,500 children and 75 tutors (teachers, doctors, and nurses) left the Port of [[Santurtzi]] in the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque]] province of [[Bizkaia]] on board the ship "Habana." Similarly, nearly 4,000 children were evacuated to the United Kingdom, also on the "Habana", with the [[HMS Hood (51)|HMS Hood]] as an escort. They became, and are still known as, "los niños de la guerra" ("the war children") or the "Gernika Generation" (as regards Basques). * September 1939 – The [[evacuations of civilians in Britain during World War II]]; at the outset of [[World War II]], [[London]] and major [[Great Britain|British]] cities were evacuated, with 1.5 million displaced in the first three days of the official evacuation. The final number of evacuees reached 3.75 million. * 1939–1940 and June 1944 – The entire population of [[Finland|Finnish]] [[Karelia]], 522,000 people, was [[Evacuation of Finnish Karelia|evacuated]] during the [[Winter War]]. Some 260,000 of these returned home during the [[Continuation War]], but were evacuated again in June 1944. * May–June 1940 – [[Operation Dynamo]] was implemented, with around 439,000 British and French troops evacuated from [[Dunkirk, France]].<ref name="youtube">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=18lsxFcDrjo</ref> * 20–23 June 1940 – 24,600 people, a third of the population, are evacuated from the [[Channel Islands]] to [[England]] and [[Scotland]] ahead of the [[Occupation of the Channel Islands#Invasion|German invasion]]. * October 1940 – 1945 – [[Evacuations of children in Germany during World War II]] * October 1941 – A mass evacuation of [[Moscow]] was ordered in the face of the threat of the war estimated 1.5 million to 3 million [[Germany|German]] [[Wehrmacht]]. Two million inhabitants were displaced within two weeks. *1942 – 1945 – Evacuation and deportation of [[Ingrian Finns]] from [[Ingria]] during and after World War II. About the entire population of Ingrian Finns (estimating 70,000 people) was evacuated from [[Leningrad Oblast|Leningrad oblast]], [[Russia]] to [[Estonia]] and [[Finland]]. Those who returned after the war faced deportations to other parts of Russia. * Autumn 1944-Spring 1945 – [[Evacuation of East Prussia]] (1.8 million people) and [[Pomerania]] (various estimates range between 3 and 7 million; see [[Flight and expulsion of Germans from Poland during and after World War II]]) * June 1944 – August 1945 – [[Evacuations of civilians in Japan during World War II]] * 1945–1951 – [[Istrian exodus]] From the end of World War II through 1953, according to various data, between 250,000 and 350,000 people emigrated from these regions * May 1950 – One hundred thousand people were evacuated from [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]], Canada during the devastating [[Red River of the North|Red River]] flood of 1950.<ref>{{cite news|title=A City Submerged – Winnipeg and the Flood of 1950 – CBC Archives|publisher=[[CBC News|CBC]]|url=http://archives.cbc.ca/environment/extreme_weather/clips/3783/|accessdate=2009-02-22 }}</ref> * Between December 10 and 24, 1950, over 100,000 [[United Nations|UN]] troops who were cut off by the [[China|Chinese]] intervention forces in Northern Korea, along with an even larger number of civilian refugees, were evacuated from the [[North Korea]]n port of [[Hungnam]] during the [[Korean War]]. * July–August 1971 – 18 million people migrated from [[Bangladesh]] (then known as [[East Pakistan]]) to [[India]] to escape the military forces of [[Pakistan]] (then known as [[West Pakistan]]). This was the largest and bloodiest exodus in human history, with 4 million dead. * 26–31 December 1974 – As a result of [[Cyclone Tracy]] destroying over 85 percent of the city, more than 60,000 people from [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin, Australia]] are evacuated from the area, leaving just 10,000 people (mainly adult males) to begin the massive cleanup. * July 1974 – The complete, spontaneous evacuation in a few hours of [[Varosha (Famagusta)#1974 to present day|Varosha]] before the advancing [[Turkey|Turkish]] army; the population feared a [[massacre]]. * 1975 – [[Operation Frequent Wind]]: thousands of [[South Vietnam]]ese and the last remaining Americans evacuate [[Ho Chi Minh City|Saigon]], capital of [[South Vietnam]], before the invading [[Vietcong]] and [[Vietnam People's Army|North Vietnamese Army]] overrun the city. * July to October 1975 – After the end of the [[Portuguese colonial war]], one million [[Portugal|Portuguese]] civilians were flown from former Portuguese colonies in Africa, mainly [[Angola]] and [[Mozambique]], back to Portugal. Thousands of flights were organized by the [[Government of Portugal|Portuguese government]], using hundreds of commercial [[airplane]]s. * 1975–1979 – [[Cambodia]]: After the [[Khmer Rouge]] take over the capital of [[Phnom Penh]], all civilians are forced to [[Khmer Rouge rule of Cambodia#Evacuation of the cities|evacuate the cities]] for the countryside, in order to create a new [[Communist]] society; 2–3 million displaced. * November 1979 – As a result of the [[1979 Mississauga train derailment]], the city of [[Mississauga]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]] was evacuated following a [[chlorine]] leak after a freight train derailed. 218,000 were displaced. * April 1986 – The [[Chernobyl disaster]] involved an evacuation of an estimated 335,000 people following a [[nuclear meltdown]] at the [[Chernobyl]] [[nuclear power]] plant in [[Ukraine]] (then part of the [[Soviet Union]]).<ref>{{cite web|title=Geographical location and extent of radioactive contamination |work=Chernobyl.info |publisher=[[Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation]] |url=http://www.chernobyl.info/index.php?navID=2 |accessdate=2007-10-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630071332/http://www.chernobyl.info/index.php?navID=2 |archivedate=2007-06-30 |df= }}</ref> * 13 August to 11 October 1990 – During the [[1990 airlift of Indians from Kuwait]] [[Air India#Awards and recognitions|Air India]] entered the [[Guinness Book of World Records]] for the most people evacuated by a civil airliner. Over 170,000 people were evacuated from [[Amman]] to [[Mumbai]]– a distance of 4,117 km- via 488 flights operated by Indian Airlines. The operation was carried out during the [[Persian Gulf War]] to evacuate Indian [[expatriate]]s from [[Kuwait]] and [[Iraq]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisismyindia.com/air-line/airindia.html |title=Air India, History of Air India, Air India Flight Services, Air India International, Passenger Operations, Awards in Air India |publisher=Thisismyindia.com |access-date=10 June 2010}}</ref> * 24–25 May 1991 – [[Operation Solomon]], covert [[Israel]]i military operation to take 14,325 [[Beta Israel|Ethiopian Jews]] to [[Israel]]. * June 1991 – [[Operation Fiery Vigil]] was the evacuation of roughly 20,000 non-essential military and [[United States Department of Defense]] civilian personnel and their dependents from [[Clark Air Base]] and [[U.S. Naval Base Subic Bay]] back to [[Contiguous United States|CONUS]] during the [[Plinian eruption|eruption]] of [[Mount Pinatubo]] in the [[Philippines]]. * February 1995 – At least 200,000 people are evacuated in the [[Netherlands]] due to flooding.<ref>{{cite news|last=Cowell|first=Alan|title=Dutch Rivers Are Receding, But Danger to Dikes Persists|publisher=''The New York Times''|date=February 3, 1995|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=990CE4D6133CF930A35751C0A963958260|accessdate=2008-06-02 }}</ref> * April 5, 1995 – Nearly 10.000 inhabitants of [[Pergamino, Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]] were evacuated for several days because of [[flood]]ing <ref>{{cite web|title=CAPITULO IV. ESTUDIO DE CASO: PERGAMINO| url= http://www.cambioglobal.org/enso/informes/anho4/Argentina/Cap%204%20ESTUDIO%20DE%20CASO%20-%20PERGAMINO.pdf |publisher= CENTRO estudios sociales y ambientales. INFORME FINAL IAI 2004 ENSO ARGENTINA |date= 2004 |language =es}}</ref> * April 1997 – Nearly 50,000 residents of Grand Forks, North Dakota were evacuated due to flooding from the Red River of the North, which overtopped levees.<ref>Shelby, A. Red River Rising: The Anatomy of a Flood and the Survival of an American City. St. Paul, MN: Minnesota Historical Society Press/Borealis Books, 2003.</ref> *July–August 1998 – Nearly 14 million people were evacuated because of massive [[flood]]ing and [[landslide]]s in north and central [[China]], and 5.6 million houses were destroyed. An additional 300,000 people were evacuated on August 7 in anticipation of a possible breach of [[Levee|dikes]] along the [[Yangtze River]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Officials stage mass evacuations in China's deadly floods|agency=Associated Press|date=August 7, 1998|url= http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/asiapcf/9808/07/china.floods.01/index.html|accessdate=2007-10-25|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080329065755/http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/asiapcf/9808/07/china.floods.01/index.html|archivedate=2008-03-29}}</ref> *1999 – The [[Kosovo War]] led to 800,000 refugees, not all of them urban residents, leaving [[Kosovo]] and being accommodated for up to three months in other parts of [[Europe]]. *September 1999 – The size of [[Hurricane Floyd]], its intensity, and its track prompted public officials to launch the largest evacuation in U.S. history, with an estimated 3 million people fleeing the storm.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fema.gov/news-release/2000/09/14/hurricane-floyd-night-remember-day-evacuation-frustration-forget|title=Hurricane Floyd – A Night To Remember, A Day Of Evacuation Frustration To Forget|last=|first=|date=September 9, 2000|website=|publisher=[[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2018-11-15}}</ref>
==21st century== [[Image:SDFIRE2007 058brightsharp.jpg|thumb|Evacuees at evacuation site [[Mira Mesa High School]]]]
* April 2001 – 77,000 inhabitants (around 2/3 of the population) of [[Vicenza]], [[Italy]]) were evacuated for several hours so that an [[UXO|unexploded bomb]], originally dropped in World War II, could be safely disarmed.<ref>{{cite news|title=Thousands Evacuated From Italian City to Detonate WWII Bomb|publisher=''People's Daily''|date=April 30, 2001|url=http://english.people.com.cn/english/200104/30/eng20010430_69000.html|accessdate=2007-10-25 }}</ref> * [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001]] – Evacuations from [[skyscraper|high-rise buildings]] across the United States. This included 3200+ survivors of the [[Collapse of the World Trade Center|World Trade Center disaster]] and inhabitants of downtown [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]]. Numerous other evacuations of high-rises in [[Chicago]], Illinois included the [[Sears Tower]] and the Thompson Building. The evacuation of New York included the largest sea evacuation in recorded history, with over 500,000 being evacuated in 9 hours by hundreds of boats.<ref name="youtube" /> * January 2002 – 300,000 residents of the city of [[Goma]], [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] were evacuated in three days due to the eruption of the [[Mount Nyiragongo]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Volcano Risk Reduction: A Case Study from Goma (DRC)|publisher=United Nations Development Programme|date=December 2004|url=http://www.undp.org/cpr/disred/documents/publications/casestudy/goma.pdf|accessdate=2007-10-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071026124011/http://www.undp.org/cpr/disred/documents/publications/casestudy/goma.pdf|archive-date=2007-10-26|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> *August 2002 – The [[2002 European floods]] led to the evacuation of 50,000 residents of [[Prague]], [[Czech Republic]], on 13 August, with a total of 200,000 Czechs during the second week of August.<ref>{{cite news|title=Prague battles flood waters|publisher=BBC News|date=August 14, 2002|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/2192288.stm|accessdate=2007-10-25 }}</ref> Elsewhere in Europe, more than 120,000 people were evacuated in the [[Germany|German]] city of [[Dresden]], 36,000 in the German state of [[Saxony-Anhalt]], and 1,500 in [[Hungary]].<ref>{{cite web|title=EADRCC Situation Report No. 2 on the Flood/CZECH Republic|publisher=Euro-Atlantic Disaster Response Coordination Centre|url=http://www.nato.int/eadrcc/floods_czech_republic/report_2002_111.pdf|accessdate=2007-10-25 }}</ref> *September 2004 – Evacuation orders were issued for over 2.8 million residents in advance of [[Hurricane Frances]], potentially the largest in Florida's history.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2004/WEATHER/09/05/hurricane.frances/index.html|title=Downgraded Frances blows across Florida|last=|first=|date=2004-09-05|website=CNN.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> FEMA later granted assistance to 229,500 applicants largely associated with relocation expenses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fema.gov/news-release/2014/08/29/ten-years-later-remembering-hurricane-frances|title=Ten Years Later: Remembering Hurricane Frances|last=|first=|date=2014-08-29|website=fema.gov|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> *July 2005 – 20,000 people were evacuated from the city of [[Birmingham]] in the [[United Kingdom]] after a security alert due to a [[bomb scare]].<ref>{{cite news|title=British police order evac of central Birmingham district|publisher=USA Today|date=July 10, 2005|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2005-07-09-birmingham-evac_x.htm|accessdate=2008-06-01 }}</ref> *August 2005 – [[Hurricane Katrina]] led to a mass evacuation of the city of [[New Orleans, Louisiana]], with approximately 80% of the city's population of 484,000 evacuating before the storm struck. *September 22, 2005 – At least 2.5 million evacuated coastal [[Texas]] and [[Louisiana]] due to the approach of [[Hurricane Rita]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hro.house.state.tx.us/interim/int79-2.pdf|title=Evacuation Planning in Texas: Before and After Rita|last=|first=|date=2006-02-14|website=|publisher=Texas House of Representatives. Government of Texas.|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> This is the second largest evacuation in U.S. history, and the third-largest peacetime evacuation in modern times. *October 2007 – More than 1.4 million people were evacuated in the Chinese provinces of [[Zhejiang]] and [[Fujian]] in anticipation of [[Typhoon Krosa (Ineng)|Typhoon Krosa]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Yanping|first=Li|title=China Evacuates 1.4 Million People as Typhoon Krosa Hits Coast|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]]|date=October 24, 2007|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601080&sid=ac5j8tBcaZ9w&refer=asia|accessdate=2007-10-25 }}</ref> *October 2007 – [[California wildfires of October 2007|California wildfires]] forced more than 900,000 people in [[Southern California]] to evacuate, making it the largest evacuation in [[California]]'s history<ref>{{cite news|last=Brennan|first=Peter J.|author2=Demian McLean |title=California Fires Rout Almost 1 Million People, Kill 5|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|date=October 24, 2007|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601103&sid=a96ks3dv.3Fo&refer=us|accessdate=2007-10-25 }}</ref> and the largest evacuation for fire in United States history.<ref>http://sosdfireblog.blogspot.com/2007/11/map-shows-massive-evacuation-area.html</ref> *May 2008 – [[2008 Sichuan earthquake]]: Approximately 200,000 people are evacuated in [[Beichuan Qiang Autonomous County|Beichuan County, China]] because of flooding fears after a [[Landslide dam|landslide created dam]] became unstable.<ref>{{cite news|title=China plans mass exodus from quake zone|publisher=CNN|date=May 29, 2008|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/asiapcf/05/30/china.earthquake/|accessdate=2008-06-01 }}</ref> *August 2008 – At least 1.9 million people were evacuated from coastal [[Louisiana]], including New Orleans, for [[Hurricane Gustav]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/hurricane/index.ssf/2008/08/11_million_people_evacuate_sou.html|title=1.9 million people evacuate south Louisiana|last=Anderson|first=Ed|date=2008-08-31|publisher=The Times-Picayune|accessdate=2008-09-01}}</ref> In western [[Cuba]], at least 300,000 people were evacuated.<ref>{{cite web|author=Will Weissert|publisher=BlueRidgeNow|date=2008-08-30|accessdate=2008-09-01|title=Gustav now Category 4, winds of 145 mph|url=http://www.blueridgenow.com/article/20080830/news/808300290}}</ref> *March 2011 – Following the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]], between 170,000 and 200,000 people are evacuated within a 50-mile radius of the [[Fukushima I Nuclear Power Plant]] in fear of large casualties due to [[radiation poisoning]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Radiation spike forces evacuations at Fukushima nuclear power station|publisher=guardian.co.uk home |date=March 16, 2011|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/16/fukushima-workers-evacuate-radiation-spikes/|accessdate=2011-03-19|location=London|first=Justin|last=McCurry}}</ref> *August 2011 – A mass evacuation stretching from [[North Carolina]] to [[New York (state)|New York]] was ordered because of [[Hurricane Irene (2011)|Hurricane Irene]] and its size.<ref>{{cite news|work=New York Times|date=August 27, 2011|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/28/us/28hurricane-irene.html|first1=Kim|last1=Severson|first2=Dan|last2=Barry|first3=Campbell|last3=Robertson|title=Damage and Flooding Scar Atlantic Seaboard}}</ref> *June 2013 – Nearly 1,000,000 people evacuated in 12 days from [[Uttarakhand]], [[India]] due to a [[flash flood]] and landslide. This operation was completed by the [[Indian Air Force]], [[ITBP]], [[National Disaster Response Force|NDRF]], and local authorities. [[Helicopter]]s were widely used because road networks were severely damaged. *October 2013 – Nearly 975,000 people (world Bank report says close to 100,000 people) were evacuated in 36 hours from the coastal areas of [[Odisha]] (more than 850,000) and [[Andhra Pradesh]] (nearly 90,000) in the face of [[Cyclone Phailin]]. This operation was completed by the [[Indian Air Force]], [[ITBP]], [[Odisha Disaster Response Force|ODRF]], and local authorities. *December 2014 – Nearly 1,000,000 people were evacuated in the eastern [[Philippines]] before [[typhoon]] [[Typhoon Hagupit (2014)|Hagupit]].<ref>https://news.yahoo.com/typhoon-hagupit-triggers-massive-evacuation-philippines-021318742.html</ref> *April 2015 – [[Operation Maitri]] was carried out by India to evacuate stranded Indian citizens and foreigners from [[Nepal]] and humanitarian relief during the Nepal earthquake of magnitude 8.8. *April 2015 – [[Operation Raahat (India)]] was carried out by India to evacuate stranded Indian citizens from [[Yemen]]. A total of 4640 Indian citizens and 960 foreign nationals were rescued.<ref>{{cite web | title=India evacuates 4,640 nationals, 960 others from Yemen | website=www.oneindia.com | date=2015-04-10 | url=http://www.oneindia.com/india/india-evacuates-4640-nationals-960-others-from-yemen-1711703.html | access-date=2015-04-11}}</ref> *May 2016 – Approximately 88,000 people were evacuated from [[Fort McMurray]] (Canada) due to a [[2016 Fort McMurray Wildfire|wildfire]] that grew out of control quickly. This was the largest evacuation in the Province of Alberta's history. Evacuees went north to [[Oil Sands]] camps, and communities to the south.<ref>{{cite news | title=Wildfire rages in Fort McMurray as evacuees settle in Edmonton | website=www.CBC.ca | date=2016-05-04 | url=http://www.cbc.ca/beta/news/canada/edmonton/wildfire-rages-in-fort-mcmurray-as-evacuees-settle-in-edmonton | access-date=2015-05-04}}</ref> *October 2016 – More than 2.5 million people were told to evacuate in [[Florida]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] and [[South Carolina]] due to the approach of [[Hurricane Matthew]], becoming the tenth most destructive in U.S. history.<ref>{{cite web | title=Hurricane Matthew batters Florida’s northeast coast; four deaths linked to storm|date=2016-08-07| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2016/10/07/hurricane-matthew-rumbles-along-floridas-coast-as-governor-warns-this-is-not-over/| access-date=2016-08-10}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.palmbeachdailynews.com/weather/hurricanes/experts-why-didn-people-evacuate-for-hurricane-matthew/t2LElTY1htABbNLu7kcMVM/?start=2|title=Why Didn't People Evacuate for Hurricane Matthew?|last=|first=|date=2017-06-01|website=Palm Beach Daily News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> *February 2017 – Evacuation of 188,000 civilians from the city of Oroville, California and other towns near the [[Oroville Dam]] due to impending failure of auxiliary spillway systems.<ref>http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/13/us/california-oroville-dam-spillway-failure/index.html</ref> *July to September 2017 - Evacuation of [[Cariboo Regional District]], British Columbia, Canada, resulted in 35,616 people under evacuation order or alert over 77 days due to a record-setting wildfire season, with 996,141 hectares burnt in 232 fires, and 60 homes and 167 other structures destroyed over 48,099 km<sup>2</sup>. No deaths were recorded.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cariboord.bc.ca/services/emergency-and-protective-services/emergency-operations-centre-eoc|title=Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) {{!}} Cariboo Regional District|website=Cariboo Regional District|language=en|access-date=2017-11-07}}</ref> *September 2017 ─ One week after [[Hurricane Harvey]] rampaged coastal Texas and Louisana, 7 million people (in [[Florida]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], and [[South Carolina]]) were told to evacuate due to [[Hurricane Irma]]. Low estimates of the actual number of evacuees is 700,000 people.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2017/09/09/magnitude-irma-drives-massive-evacuation-from-florida/cdbZjGJrvgIF0Todpws4VJ/story.html}}</ref>
